results.description:
WOMEN ONLY EVENT. Meeting a MAN in NYC is not the easiest of tasks. What makes it even tougher is if you don't have a reliable friend to help navigate the NYC single scene. 

Come meet your new BFF at our Ladies Networking Night!

Every single woman needs a dependable friend, equally motivated to go out with you to parties, clubs, bars, and everything else a single women doesn't want to hit "solo." 

Meet up to 30 other fabulous women (20s & 30s) at our upscale speed networking event. Also, enjoy $4 beer and $5 wine drink specials. 

We'll start you off in groups where you'll get to meet 3-4 women at a time and then we'll transition to a less formal mixer where you all can mingle at your leisure. 

This is a PREPAY ONLY EVENT. NO tickets sold at the door.

1st 5 women to get tickets save $5 by using discount code "BFF" at checkout ($20). MUST BUY TICKET IN ADVANCE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wing/dates/Nov-04-2015_at_0730PM

Why does your RSVP say +30?  This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. 30+ women will be attending. 

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/wing/dates/Nov-04-2015_at_0730PM
results.name: Ladies Networking Night / Meet Your New BFF (20s & 30s) PREPAY ONLY

group.name: NYC Introverts That Want To Be Extroverts

results.description:
This is a casual in-store wine tasting event, usually on the 1st Wednesday of every month, featuring a selection of 3 wines and light refreshments.

Join the Sipper's Delight Wine Tasting Social Club at The Artisan Collective for wine sipping and socializing in a fun and unpretentious environment.  Each month we will taste and discuss three new wines.  This event is a great way to develop your wine tasting skills, learn about different wines and meet other wine enthusiasts!

Upcoming Tasting Dates & Themes

• 7/1:  Drink Local (NY & NJ Wines)

• 8/5:  South African Wines

• 9/2 - Italian Wines Part I (Northern Italy)

• 10/7 - Italian Wines Part II (Southern Italy & Islands)

Admission: $10

Directions:  NJ Transit to Newark Penn Station or Broad Street Station.

From Newark Penn Station: Take the Light Rail to NJ PAC/Center Street and walk approximately 2 blocks West to the corner of Central & Halsey Street (cross Broad Street). Turn left onto Halsey and walk to the Artisan Collective, located at 25 Halsey Street.

From Broad Street: Take the Light Rail to Washington Park.  Turn right onto Washington Street, then left onto Halsey Street.  Walk 1.5 blocks South on Halsey Street (cross Central Ave) to the Artisan Collective, located at 25 Halsey Street.
results.name: Wine Tasting Wednesdays

group.name: Sipper's Delight Wine Tasting Social Club - NJ/NY

results.description:
Come rehearsal with us at our regular location, the Music Conservatory of Westchester! No need to prepare, just show up with your instrument and get ready to play. We have around 30-40 people at most rehearsals (most members are not on the Meetup page) so don't worry, you will have a full orchestra to play with.

RSVP on Meetup to let us know you're coming, or email [masked].

Parking: The Conservatory asks that orchestra musicians *not* park in the Conservatory parking lot unless you are a tuition paying student of either the Conservatory of the Steffi Nossen School of Dance. Street parking is free after 6pm, and there is a large municipal lot across Central Ave from City Limits (24hr meters in the lot).

The first rehearsal is free. Subsequent rehearsals are $10/rehearsal or a discounted annual rate.
results.how_to_find_us: Northern end of Central Ave, just south of City Limits Diner and across rt. 119 from the County Center
results.name: Rehearse with the New Westchester Symphony Orchestra

results.description:
Come join us for our climbing Meetup!!

As usual, everyone is welcome to join in on the fun as long as you're at least 18 years old, whether you’re a complete beginner just looking to give the sport a try or a seasoned veteran that can show the best of us a few new tricks. Bring your friends too, even if they've never tried climbing before. We'll make sure everybody is set up and having a blast. Age and strength don't even matter, everybody has fun.

1st time climbers at The Rock Club get in for FREE! All you have to do is rent a harness and shoes for $9. Returning Meetupers get a discounted daypass rate of $15. And be sure to have a look out at the gym for other special Meetup discounts.

We also host a special Meetup 101 class from 7:30 - 9pm for Meetup members only. When multiple people sign-up for the class you pay only $45 ($15 discount!).

Reserve your spot with the booking button and enter the promo code "Meetup" on the booking page.

IMPORTANT!!  This offer has restrictions. It is only valid for the Weds night Meetup 101 class, you must already be a meetup member and RSVP for the meetup as well (no guests).

If this is your first time climbing just come on in and join the group. There’s no need to take the class just yet. You’ll be able to join other Meetup members who already have their belay certification. This way you’ll be able to get up and on the wall right away! When you decide that you absolutely love climbing (which you will!), then you can sign up for the class the following week.

As a heads up, when you come into the gym, the front desk staff will get you set up with gear and get you in the system. There will also be name tags for everyone. Wear them with pride so everyone knows who’s a part of Meetup!

DETAILS - Please read carefully!

RSVPing and Questions:
If you're attending the belay course you MUST call TRC to reserve your space.
If you have any questions, please email TRC directly: [url][masked][/url]

Time:
The closer to 7pm you arrive, the better. The 101 class starts at 7:30 sharp.

Directions & Transportation:
Please save time and aggravation by getting directions from our website (BEFORE you call or email us for directions :-). If you're coming on Metro North as a group (2 or more people!) we'll pick you up from the train station. Use the message baord to connect with other riders.  Just give us a call to let us know when you'll arrive. Go to the taxi stand in front of the station building!

We're looking forward to seeing you soon!
results.name: Weekly Climbing Meetup - New members climb for free!!

group.name: The New York Metro Rock Climbing Meetup

results.description:
Your inner child needs to know that it is safe, loved, acknowledged and embraced. In our meditation we will gift our inner child with the light and love of its highest potential, reclaiming our innocence, creativity and open heart. 

Reiki can help reduce physical pain, balance your energy system, increase mental clarity, enhance creativity, and facilitate personal healing and spiritual growth.

Please bring a childhood photo of yourself.


Following our meditation we will anchor this healing with 60 minutes of a Reiki share.
results.name: Healing The Inner Child Meditation and Reiki Share

results.description:
The programming language night group meets once a month to explore the uses of unfamiliar (to us (mostly)) languages. We like to find what they can teach us over the course of a few hours and explore how we might use them (or might not) in the future.

We're exploring x86 assembly language this month, and will choose another language for the months following. You can find an IDE for x86 at (http://www.rayseyfarth.com/ebe/) which may be helpful.

[PLEASE NOTE: All minors must be accompanied by parent and or guardian.]

MakerBar is a 501(c)3 NJ Non-Profit Organization.. All donations are tax deductible.....consider donating today...Help keep the H@ck3ry alive! 

Interested in membership? Speak to one of our members about the many benefits of membership as well as the outstanding community that is Hoboken's MakerBar. Hudson County's one and only Hackerspace.

http://www.makerbar.com

twitter: @MakerBar

facebook: http://www.facebook.com/TheMakerBar
results.name: Programming Language Night: x86 edition

results.description:
The Place:

Noreetuh is a casual Hawaiian inspired restaurant located at 128 First Avenue in the East Village of New York City by Chef Chung Chow and his partners Gerald San Jose and Jin Ahn. The menu has strong ties in Japanese, Korean and Filipino cuisines and is inspired from his influences growing up in Hawaii and living in Japan.

The restaurant’s goal is to create an atmosphere where guests can enjoy artfully crafted food paired with an approachable wine list in an enjoyable and casual environment, thus lending to the name noreetuh, which means playground in Korean.

Please Note: Fay will be the host for this Meetup.


RSVPs:

Please don't RSVP unless you are sure you can go. I do notice the people who RSVP and then cancel which really isn't fair to everyone else. I reserve the right to give priority to people who don't do this in the future. I'm not trying to be mean or anything but it makes it much harder for me when people take spots and then cancel either quickly or last minute. Obviously more notice is better but please try to only sign up (for waitlist as well) if you know you can come.

Also even if the meetup is full please do put your name on the waitlist. I always give priority to people on the waitlist if spots open up. I will also try to give an idea in advance if it looks like there might be more spots. Also, if there are a lot of people on the waitlist I will try to get more seats, although for reservations made far in advance I am unlikely to succeed. At very least it will let me know what kinds of restaurants are popular so I can schedule more of those in the future. Thanks.
results.name: Noreetuh- Hawaiin Food

results.description:
From a Buddhist perspective, we are all suffering from painful attachments that can manifest as addiction, depression, confusion, and powerlessness. The teachings of Buddha provide a clear and simple pathway to freedom from these negative states of mind.

Through practicing time tested meditation techniques, we will reduce and eventually eliminate these painful mental habits.
$15.00 Suggested donation. No one turned away for lack of funds.

results.description:
What are people saying about this class?!  Where the heck have you been all my life!?  This a true Kickboxing class taught by an experienced professional kick boxer and 3rd degree Black Belt Instructor; with a degree in Exercise physiology and biomechanics. As well as first aid and CPR, AED Certified. We incorporate all aspects of the trade as well as cardio and contact training. The time is now; get in on the act. 

State of the Art Kickboxing and self defense all combined into one heck of a cardio pulsing session that is guaranteed to help you to acheive your results!

results.description:
This fall, Warren Miller Entertainment will release its 66th snowsports film, Chasing Shadows. Watch JT Holmes, Seth Wescott, Caroline Gleich, Steven Nyman, and more as they pursue turns in Chamonix, Alaska’s Chugach, Utah’s Wasatch and the mightiest range of them all: the Himalaya. These athletes are masters in their element, and with every cliff drop, perfect line and knee-deep powder turn, they motivate us. Take a glimpse into the world of the U.S. freestyle team and see the dynamics of snowsports that live on the fringe, like monoskiing, powsurfing and speed riding. Explore what it means to be inspired, and what it is about exotic locations and snow-covered summits that keep us searching for more. Winter starts with Warren Miller.

To Purchase tickets: https://tickets.tarrytownmusichall.org/eventperformances.asp?evt=1715

https://youtu.be/WF1D3aML-3I
results.name: Warren Miller's film "Chasing Shadows" in Tarrytown

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and TurnOn. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in NYC?

We play 3 communication game (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). Imagine meeting new people in an environment where people felt comfortable to be themselves. That's what we have created.

It's a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation.

You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can have the life that you want.

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. In an hour and some you may even forget for a moment you are in New York City.

OneTaste NYC is an organization teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without having to actually do the practice (or remove any clothing!).

It's a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good. This allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

Come early, doors close at 8:10p.  

COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]


Can't make this one?  Visit us at www.turnonny.us

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8OWkv9zms4E
results.name: TurnON New York City

results.description:
Leadership and Lipstick

Ladies, this is one of my favorite signature classes that I offer as Woman's Coach and I'd love for you to join and receive the benefits.  It ties in concepts like what is leadership, why women make the best leaders and entrepreneurs, and what can you do TODAY to be an amazing leader in your life.

It's one of my favorite topics to discuss so please bring questions.  Please dress comfortably, make some tea/coffee, and put the kids to sleep.  This is guaranteed to be a great class!

Questions to ask yourself:

1.  What does leadership mean to you?

2.  How do you think women operate as leaders?

3.  How do you think being a woman has impacted your leadership skills?


What else?

Post class we can talk about how I can help you with any urgent questions/topics that come up in your life where you'd like to improve as a leader.
results.how_to_find_us: Postponed for a later date.
results.name: POSTPONED: Leadership and Lipstick Teleclass

results.description:
Join us the 1st Wednesday every third month - next date is in March - for a new art opening of a local NY artist. Musical performances by local musicians: classical and jazz guitar, and vocalists are every Wednesday evening and a new musician is feature the first Wednesday of every month.


If you have a musical talent, bring your instrument and/or your voice and be part of the performance.

If you are a NY artist, please submit your work (slides, pix) to the organizer for a future exhibit.

This MeetUp is at The Red Pipe Cafe at 71-60 Austin Street, in Forest Hills.  The Red Pipe is an all organic cafe with great coffee and teas, and delicious food choices. Check them out on Google.

results.description:
TurnOn - yourself, your relationships, your sex. This is the place to excavate what you truly desire. Have you wondered how to create the relationships you want? Experience the intimacy you crave? Where you can say the honest truth to your partner, your family, your lover and yet stay grounded in yourself?

We believe that no matter what type of relationship you desire, human connection is at the basis of genuine relating. We play a set of intimate communication games that let you sharpen your relating skills and hone your attention. You get to shed off the layers that keep us from being seen, be vulnerable and feel more alive. We play 3 games (you can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you). It's a refreshing change from the typical “Hi, how are you?” conversation. You get the opportunity to examine yourself. Through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses.

What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to say what's real. At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation. What class you can take and what we have to offer so you can work towards having the intimacy you want.

Come early, doors close at 8:10p. COST TO ATTEND IS $10.

For questions contact [masked] |[masked]

Can't make this one? Visit us at www.turnonny.us
https://youtu.be/8OWkv9zms4E
results.name: TurnON New York City

We're heading to Silvana in Harlem for a night of free expression. Where are you on the hero journey's? What is your story? Tell us and the rest of the Harlem community through spoken word, a funny story, or a song. The Versey team will be there to capture some of the best moments of the night.

Media is being owned by fewer and fewer corporations, so here at Versey we're proud to support one of the few independent and truly local media -open mics. They are vital to a community by honing local talent and giving community members a platform for their art. 

Founded by Gregrian Vassell, a developer with a decade of experience in mobile development at Intel, Versey is a mobile app that allows you to record mini podcasts. Support one of the few black-owned startups and meet us for a verse or two. Also, when you record a verse on Versey and share it on social media you'll get a drink-on us!


So come through for a night of free expression and creative range!

results.description:
Come and have a great time enjoy a great workout with great people while potentially  getting a fantastic sunrise! :)  Check out the photos of prior sunrise hikes !!

Please adhere to the two golden rules!

 1) Hike Safe

2) Have Fun  :)

Please try to be the timely as the purpose of this hike is to catch the sunrise. If you are going to be late please leave a message on the meet up board.

Directions From NY Route 9D, look for Bob's Corner Store in Beacon. Turn east onto Howland Avenue. then immediately turn right into the parking area for Scenic Hudson's Mount Beacon Park.


Public Transportation: Metro-North Hudson Line to Beacon station -- walk uphill to trailhead

Trail info- We will be taking the steps from the Gateway park to the Red trail. The trail is 6 or 7 switchbacks up to the old casino with a very rewarding lookout point where you can see sweeping views of the Hudson River and surrounding area.

Distance: 4 miles round trip


The First 0.8 miles of this hike is hard, and very steep with 1000ft. elevation gain. Mount Beacon is the second highest point in the Hudson Highlands. Depending on the map, it may be called Mount Beacon or Beacon Mountain. The mountain consists of two peaks. The northern peak is 1531ft and has a series of radio antennas on its summit. The higher southern peak is 1610ft and has a lookout tower on its summit. On a clear morning we will see the NYC skyline lights from the summit as well as views of the town of Beacon and the majority of the Highlands (including Storm King, Breakneck Ridge, and little Sugarloaf).


You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.


If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

results.description:
Positive Connections for Success is a more relaxed and personal networking group for business professionals looking to build relationships and grow their business through referrals.

We focus on:

• Networking: Building relationships and earning each others trust to become referral partners

• Education: Understanding your business and helping you articulate your business

• Leadership: Leaders of the round table philosophy, every member is a leader of this group


We follow a structured meeting agenda starting with networking to develop relationships, giving us time to talk and get to know each other while having a warm breakfast, followed by:

• One Minute Elevator Pitch

• Business Presentations with Q&A and feedback (we have a large screen & clicker/pointer available for powerpoint presentations)

• Brainstorming Session, Successes & Referrals to Help Each Others Businesses grow

• Lots of Fun in the Process

"We Refer Business Partners, Not Business Cards!"

This is a group with category/specialty specific members (only one member per category/speciality).
Please view our sponsors page or contact us to verify your industry, category and specialty, before attending a meeting so as to not be in conflict with a group member.

We meet every Thursday morning from 7:00 AM to 8:30 AM and welcome guests to come and experience the group and then apply to join.

Non-members/guests pay a $10 fee to attend, which includes a warm served breakfast of their choosing and we ask to please be prepared with a one minute elevator pitch presenting:

• who you are

• type of business

• who would be a good referral for you


Current positions that we are interviewing, to build relationships with and pass referrals to include:

• Attorney

• Mortgage Broker

• Realtor

• Printer

• Landscaper

• Limo or car service

• Painter

• Plumber

• And more...

Please contact us for information or if you have any questions.

We look forward to seeing you at our next meetup!

results.description:
Panels and Presenters

Reading Terror: Representations and Resistance

Panels and Presenters (in order of schedule)

Welcome Panel on Thursday – “Constructing and Inhabiting the Spaces of Terror”:

 Matthew Armstrong (Independent Researcher) – “Reading the GWOT: The Relationship between the Global War on Terror and Global Literacy.”  Shaza Elsheshtawy (The New School for Social Research) – “Cairo’sAshwa’iyyat: Informal Settlement Formation & the (Discursive) Construction of Terror.”  Sally Sharif (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “The Aesthetics of Jihad: A Study of Videos Released by the Islamic State.”  Hamza Muhammad Iqbal (Habib University) – “Karachi and Terror.”

1A. Terror Today

 Peter M. Boudreau  (Tufts University) – “Touch Me in the Morning: Finding Community in Ron Athey’sDissociative Sparkle.”  Vincent Sallé (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “Can terror be funny?”  Anne-Gabrielle Roussel (Brown University) – “French government’s fight against terrorism: the websitestop-djihadisme.gouv.fr

1B. Turning Terror into Text

 Ruth Riftin (University of Virginia) – “The Transmission of Terror: How the Witnesses of the Saint-Bartholomew’s Day Massacre turn their horrific experiences into text.”  Noni Carter (Columbia University) – “Archiving Terror and the Slave Sublime: Marlon James’The Book of Night Womenand its contribution to the politics of remembering.”  Malte Fabian Rauch (The New School for Social Research) – “An Aesthetic of Remembrance: Representing Atrocity in the Novel.”  Dolores Resano (University of Barcelona) – “9/11, Hero-cops and Counter-discourse in Jess Walter’sThe Zero

1C.  Terror on the Stage

 James Rumsey-Merlan (Princeton University) – “Stage Fright.”  Enzo Vasquez Toral (Princeton University) – “Brazilian Theater under Dictatorship and the Shinning Path: Reading Brechtian Influences as Inspiration and Response to Terror in Theatrical Discourse.”  Maria-Cristina Necula (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “Raising the Iron Curtain: The Bucharest Opera Resistance.”

2A. Terror and the Body

 Rebeccah Leiby (Boston University) – “Sublime Terror and the Danger of Serenity.”  Daniela Jiménez (University of California, Los Angeles) – “‘Every Time a Corpse Enters the Picture…’: Gothic and Evitamania inSanta Evita.”

 Colin Burns (Fordham University) – “Performing the Body in Pain: Body Art in Don DeLillo’sFalling Man

2B.  Terror and Trauma

 Diviani Chaudhuri (SUNY Binghamton) – “Reading the Landscape of Terror in Partitioned Nations: India/Pakistan and Israel/Palestine.”  Kaitlyn Martin Fox (Boston University) – “Wstawàch: Reading Terror as Awakening to the Unclaimed Past in Primo Levi’s Survival in Auschwitz and The Reawakening” Laurel Billings (University of Michigan) – “9/11’s Queer Poetics: Radical Love and Everyday Loss W.H. Auden’s ‘September 1, 1939’ and Claudia Rankin’s ‘Don’t Let Me Be Lonely’.”

2C.  The Revolutionary Spirit of Terror

 Luis A. Lei (The New School for Social Research) – “Absolute Freedom and Revolutionary Terror in China.”  Yannleon Chen (University of Arizona) – “The Different Faces of Terror: Facets of Violence and Terror in the RAF and BRD.”  Nick Olson (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “TBD”

3A. Terror in Latin America

 Philip Johnson (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “Exceptional State to Caliphate: the Journey of a Symbol.”  Ruth Halvey (Princeton University) – “Countering Narco Theatricality: Photojournalism and the Corpse in Contemporary Mexico.”  Andrea Adhara Gaytán Cuesta (Rutgers University) – “De lamano peluda a la Santa Muerte: Zombies, Death, Bodies and collective fear in Mexican daily life.”

3B.  Existential Terror

 Zunaira Yousaf (Independent Researcher) – “Terror and the Self.”  Paula Libfeld (The New School for Social Research) – “Disrupting the Instant: Levinas and Ethical Representations of the Holocaust.”  Marc Rickenbach (The Graduate Center, CUNY) – “Tone-Deaf Subjects, Overhearing Noise: Robbe Grillet’s Jealousy and Heidegger’s Hebel.”

3C. Memorializing (Victims of) Terror

 Ruichuan Wu (University of Pennsylvania) – “Pyramid of Skulls (​

Jingguan

)​: Ritualizing Terror in Early Chinese Military Culture”  Senem Guler-Biyikli (University of Pittsburgh) – “Away From the National Memorials: Narrative and Form at the Local 9/11 Memorials.”  Anila Gill (New York University) – “

Reflecting Absence

: History, Memory, and Void in the 9/11 Memorial Museum.”
results.name: Reading Terror: Representations and Resistance

results.description:
Register for Webinar

Hello DataSift Meetup Members! It's been a while since we all got together for a drink. We're working on some great events in the next few months, but in the meantime we wanted to extend a special invitation to attend one of our worldwide webinars. Even if the time doesn't work for you, register and you'll get access to the recording once it's over.

At DataSift we're constantly looking for ways to help customers build better insights from data. We're increasingly looking to data science techniques to achieve this.

One area we're currently working on is moving beyond keywords when building filters and classifiers. If you're a member of DataSift FORUM you'll be aware that we recently released our Keyword Relationship Explorer tool. This tool was a first step towards our goal.

Join us for our first in a series of webinars for the DataSift FORUM where you will:

• Understand how we built the model that sits behind the tool

• Learn how you can build your own model from your own data

• See how we're looking to build the concept of similarity into our platform and how it will transform the way customers will filter and classify data

Register for Webinar

results.description:
The Tow Center for Digital Journalism is hosting Farai Chideya and Josh Begley of The Intercept, along with Columbia Journalism School's Marguerite Holloway for a Tow Tea on "Parsing Tech Talk."  The discussion will focus on tips and strategies for effectively reporting on science, medicine and technology - as well as how best to communicate these complex topics to a general audience.


RSVP Recommended  @  http://bit.ly/1WwoNGj


A little about the panelists: 

Josh Begley: Josh Begley is a data artist and web developer based in Brooklyn. He is currently a reseach editor at 'The Intercept'. He is the creator of Metadata+, an iPhone app that tracks U.S. drone strikes. His work has appeared in Wired, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, The Guardian, New York Magazine, and at the New Museum of Contemporary Art.

Farai Chideya: Farai Chideya is a reporter, political and cultural analyst, and educator. Over the years she has worked in print, television, radio, and digital media; covered every Presidential election since 1996; and traveled to 26 countries and 48 states to report, learn, and explore.


Marguerite Holloway: Marguerite Holloway is an Associate Professor of Professional Practice and Director, Science & Environmental Journalism at Columbia University. She has written about science—including natural history, environmental issues, public health, physics, neuroscience and women in science—for publications including the New York Times, Discover, Natural History,Wired and Scientific American, where she was a long-time writer and editor.
results.name: Tow Tea: Parsing Tech Talk

results.description:
Weather: Please check back here for any weather updates and/or cancellations.

Transit: 2 or 5 trains to E 174th St stop and short walk. 5 train runs express until 7PM from E 149th St-Third Ave to E 180th St. BX17, BX21 and BX11 within walking distance.

Ready? Play.
_____________________________________________________

What will we be doing at the Meetup?
We will be meeting at the tennis courts for some friendly rallying, doubles, and singles play*. This meetup is open to players at any skill level; from beginner to advanced.

*For those of you who are interested in singles play, please keep in mind that the ability to play singles predicates on the amount of members who have RSVPed as well as court availability at the meetup event's venue. We cannot guarantee singles play in every instance.

How long will the meetup be?
The time listed for the meetup event is when you can expect to the event host to be there. If you would like to arrive earlier or later than the start time listed, please leave a comment in the meetup event you plan to attend. This will give everyone in attendance a good representation of who is showing up at what time.

What will it be like?
Our group is very friendly and loosely organized to allow for a fun experience.

Upon arrival, our event host will announce which court they are on in the comments of the meetup event. If you have a smartphone, we strongly suggest that you download the Meetup app for iPhone or Android to make communication easier.

When you arrive at the courts, look for the event host listed or other members of the group playing on (or near) the courts listed. Use the photos of each host/member on the website as a frame of reference.


Introduce yourself. Let the host know your level of play and you will be assigned to a court immediately.

Do members need to bring anything?
All members must bring their own racquet. Unfortunately, we do not supply racquets.

All members are encouraged to bring a fresh can of new balls. You can always use a marker to mark your initials on your ball if you would like to keep them for future play. Please keep in mind that tennis balls only last a couple of days after taking them out of the can before they lose their bounce.

If you plan to donate to the group, you can leave your donation with the meetup event host or the head organizer, Frank, if he’s in attendance. All donations go towards the fees required to organize the meetup.

Who should come? Are newcomers welcome?
Our meetup event is open to all players whether they're an absolute beginner or an advanced player. Players will be matched up with others based on their skill level. Beginners will be given an opportunity to play with higher level players so they can gain more experience with higher consistency.

It is a high priority for our group to help beginners increase their skill and become better players. If you are reading this and are an absolute beginner, please don't be intimidated. We want you to join us and have fun.

What should a newcomer expect?
If you're new to the group, you'll learn very quickly that our community is extremely friendly. We have a colorful cast of characters from all walks of life who are ready and willing to have a good time.

Whether you're interested in easy-going rallying or competitive play, we can accommodate you.

Questions?
If you have any other questions, concerns, or comments; please send them to our head organizer, Frank Tirado via email.

results.description:
Meet the leaders of Axial, Fivver, PRIV and Handy - four exciting gig/shared economy start-ups you should get to know.  MIT Sloan Fellow Michael Schrage will facilitate a panel discussion on the hows and whys of making these business models succeed for customers, participants and investors alike.


What skills and talents win? What management cliches are doomed to obsolete anachronisms? What ways to measure, match and monetize human capital in these marketplaces work best? Is there a tad too much froth?

In market sectors from beauty and wellness to talent to enterprise support, the opportunities for ingenuity and impact appear rife. This panel examines how real they are.

Schedule


> 5:30 - 6:00 pm Registration and Networking
> 6:00 - 7:30 pm Panel Discussion and Q&A
> 7:30 - 8:30 pm Drinks and Networking

TO REGISTER, PLEASE GO TO OUR SITE AND REGISTER THROUGH EVENTBRITE:

http://mitefnyc.org/eventbrite-events/?event=18955840429


Moderator:


Michael Schrage
Research Fellow, MIT Center for Digital Business
Visiting Fellow, Imperial College Dept. of Innovation and Entrepreneurship
</a>

A fellow with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Sloan School's Initiative on the Digital Economy and a visiting scholar at Imperial College’s Innovation and Entrepreneurship program, Michael Schrage is author of <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Innovators-Hypothesis-Cheap-Experiments-Worth/dp/0262028360/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1443823185&sr=8-1&keywords=Michael+Schrage">’The Innovator’s Hypothesis’ [MIT Press 2014] and ‘Who Do You Want Your Customers To Become?’ [Harvard Business Review Press 2012]. His research, writing and advisory work focuses on the ‘behavioral economics’ of models, prototypes and experiments as collaborative media for managing ‘innovation risk.’ He describes this as ‘behavioral OR.’

His current research explores the role of two-sided markets and ’network effects’ in shaping innovation and human capital investment. He is an angel investor in several digital media and ‘machine learning’ start-ups. A featured and top trafficked blogger for the Harvard Business Review site, his work has been published the Sloan Management Review, the Financial Times, The Wall Street Journal, the Nikkei Asian Review, the CACM as well as peer-reviewed publications.

Panelists:

Umang Dua
Founder and COO at Handy
</a>

As Handy’s COO, Umang plays a pivotal role in increasing Handy’s footprint, both across North America and abroad, spearheading new market rollout and managing the company’s aggressive growth. From home cleaning to handyman services, Handy instantly matches thousands of customers every week with trusted professionals in cities all around the world. With a seamless 60-second booking process, secure payment, and a 100% money-back guarantee, Handy is the easiest, most convenient way to book home services.

While in college, Umang founded his first startup College Connect, an online platform that connected international college and business school applicants with enrolled students around the world. After college, Umang worked briefly at McKinsey & Company but soon left to study at Harvard Business School. It was there that Umang met his Handy co-founder, Oisin Hanrahan. In 2012, the two launched Handy as the on-demand platform for home services, connecting consumers with quality home service professionals.

Currently living in New York, Umang is passionate about global politics and an avid traveler.

David Manela
Chief Revenue Officer at Fiverr
<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pub/david-manela/0/527/83b">

David Manela is the Chief Revenue Officer of Fiverr, the world’s largest marketplace for creative and professional services. As Fiverr’s CRO, he is responsible for driving Fiverr's aggressive growth, including acquisition, engagement, and category strategies across all Fiverr 150+ marketplace categories. Prior to Fiverr, David played a pivotal role at ideel, where he led the company’s marketing, merchandising, planning, and e-commerce functions. He helped grow the company from a startup to an online retailer of $130M+, earning recognition from Inc. magazine as “America’s Fastest Growing Private Company.” David earned his MBA in finance from Rouen Graduate School of Management and an MA in European history from the University of Rouen in France. He and his wife live in New York City with their two children.

Allison Tepley
SVP Marketing & Business Development at AXIAL.net
</a>

Axial, founded in 2009, provides a network of 20,000 CEOs, buyers, lenders, investors and advisors with the keys to run business development activities. Prior to Axial, Allison held senior marketing roles at Google, AOL and several start-ups prior to management consulting at BCG.  She graduated from Harvard Business School in 2005.

Joseph Terzi
Co-Founder/CEO at PRIV
<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pub/joseph-terzi/8a/259/964">

Since 2010, Joseph has been developing iOS, Android, and web applications. He developed multiple hi tech apps for national luxury beauty brands, as well as innovative software solutions for the management and operations of dispatch-orientated service businesses that rely on fast, location based, peer-to-peer communication. Joseph still works closely with PRIV CTO in all matters relating to tech.

Joseph graduated from Columbia University in 2004. He has founded and run companies in diverse sectors including land development and fashion.

results.description:
Note: This is the opening reception of a new Exhibition at the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany. This event is free of charge, but REGISTRATION AT EVENTBRITE is REQUIRED after your RSVP, or you may not get access to the event, even if you RSVP'd here.


After your RSVP here in the group, please proceed to

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/celia-rogge-exhibition-opening-tickets-18763903340


immediately to secure your spot.

Briefly about the artist

Celia Rogge has built a strong international reputation as a photographer over the past 10 years and has had her work exhibited extensively.

The Museum of the City of New York recently included her work (Calm After The Storm…) in the “Rising Waters 2.0” exhibition.

What to find at the Exhibition
At the General Consulate you will find a number of pieces included from her vibrant series New York Reflections. The reflections of New York architecture elevate the contours of this metropolis to another perceptive level. Before unseen ornamental structures are filtered through the transformative power of light. The London Reflections series here is represented by the images “St Pauls…”

Pieces from the Calliope series offer an entirely different projection of the transformative power of light through the use of infrared photography, which reflects daylight at a different frequency. Calliope, the photographer’s muse, is captured using this unusual type of photography - allowing for the viewer to transcend into an ethereal otherworldliness.

Other works included in this show at the General Consulate of Germany show her continued love of structure, architecture and reflective light. In the Palais Lichtenau Enfilades the viewer is enticed to step through the image into another world. And the pieces of her Sandy andRiverside series show the continued love of and fascination with the City of New York.

More about the artist
German born photographer Celia Rogge has lived and worked in New York since the mid-1990s but has also called Berlin, London, Washington and Montreux her home. She studied at the International Center of Photography (ICP) in Manhattan, Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service and at the LSE in London.

In the United States she is represented by the renowned Galerie Mourlot in New York and in Germany by Galerie Friedmann Hahn in Berlin.


Ongoing Exhibit Hours (after the Opening Reception)

Thursday, November 5 – Friday, November 27, 2015

Hours: Mon-Fri 9:00am – 5:00pm

 (closed on weekends)
Admission is always free.

Official Site:

http://www.germany.info/Vertretung/usa/en/__events/GKs/NEWY/2015/11/08__Rogge.html?archive=2010496

How do I get there by subway?

Your best bet is the 6 Train to 51st Street, with more options form Grand Central Terminal (4/5/6/7), but since this is at 1st Ave and 49th, there is going to be a bit of a walk involved, keep that in mind for your timing.

I hope to see you there, please don't forget to register at Eventbrite (see link atop) for guaranteed access. And - as always - change your RSVP status if your plans change. We appreciate it very much!

Thomas

[masked]

[masked]

Join DM Kyle Wagenblast as he recreates the classic D&D 2E module "Adam's Wrath" by Lisa Smedman. This is an adventure in the Ravenloft setting, updated to D&D 5E, and is for characters of 5th level.

In the domain of Lamordia, Doctor Victor Mordenheim created Adam, cobbling the creature together from parts of human corpses. Now, years later, Adam wants revenge. Adam wants Elise, Victor's wife. Adam wants Victor dead.

The players' ship founders on the coast of the domain of Lamordia. A vicious storm leaves them washed ashore, cold and hungry on the ice-bound Isle of Agony... then, the terror begins.

results.description:
All Bisexual, Non-monosexual, and all other Queer-identified and Bi-friendly people are invited to come join people from the greater NYC Area in a lively topic oriented discussion at BiRequest's famously open, non-judgmental, safe space. If you can't make it to the meeting, feel free to join everyone afterward around  "eight-fifteenish" for dinner.

about us: Thanks to the dedication and hard work of many good bisexual folk, BiRequest is a bisexual social discussion group serving the New York City metropolitan area since January 1994. We provide a safe space for bisexuals and bi-friendly people to gather and discuss issues of importance to us.

We're a co-ed group for adults from 18 to 80-plus who meet twice a month every 1st and 3rd Thursday evening at NYC's LGBT Center in the West Village. The meetings are moderated and focused on a discussion topic but not limited to that week's topic.

After the discussion group session, at 8 o'clock we go to dinner at a nearby, reasonably-priced restaurant for socializing and more informal discussion. We also have occasional social events such as movie nights, parties, and much more. Join us for a meeting or event and find the community you've been looking for!

People who can't make it to the meeting are invited to join our private online group BiRequest on Yahoo or on our Facebook Page BiRequest on Facebook.

This page has images of the openings we will be attending, so if you dont see them and you are........


1) viewing this page on the Meetup app click the description tab to view the list of galley openings.  

2) using an Android mobile browser open your browser's settings menu and click ''Request Desktop Site". 

3) using  Apple IOS then click the desktop site button at the bottom of the page. 

For those new to the Hop you might be wondering how you will find the group. Well below is a lovely pictures of myself. Study my face carefully and commit it to memory. Now that I am burned into your hippocampus simply look for me hovering near the entrance to the first gallery.

Just a little more business...


Every week I receive emails from new members asking if there is a fee to join or attend the Thursday Night Gallery Hop. So rather than answer each email individually I'll kill a whole flock of birds with one stone.     


THE HOP IS, ALWAYS HAS BEEN, AND WILL REMAIN COMPLETELY FREE    


That said if you would like to help offset my organizer fees or buy me a post-hop bourbon you are more than welcome to click the 'chip in' button on the left side of this page. But let me reiterate contributions while appreciated are NOT required.

Look forward to seeing everyone

Todd

results.description:
*This event is for young professionals between the ages of 22 and 35. 

Please join us on Thursday, November 5th, at 6 pm for a night of learning and networking! 

At our kick-off event, we will be joined by Jim Cirtin who currently leads Spencer Stuart’s North American CEO Practice. Prior to that, he spent five years at McKinsey & Company and was an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Co. Jim graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Vassar College in 1981 and served as a trustee on the school’s Board of Directors for 12 years, co-chairing the Nominating Committee. He received his M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1986, earning first- and second-year honors and graduating with distinction. Jim is also the author of many professional development books-most recently the "Career Playbook". At the event, he will give a talk about his advice to young people who are at the early stages of their careers and will provide signed copies of his book as well. 

In order to attend the event, you have to register following the link below: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1v13CcdVI-CsIU4rThPVCYI3cKXpL9HsQIW1SMugwiRI/viewform?c=0&w=1


The event is near Grand Central. Upon the completion of the registration form, you will receive the exact location in your confirmation email.

Looking forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
This modern take on the classic American farmhouse sets fun, geometric volumes under a gabled roof. 

The house represents the family’s core commitment to sustainable living where food is grown in their organic garden, meals are created and shared together, and lessons in social and environmental responsibility are a part of everyday living. 

A cost-effective Larsen truss assembly, built on-site and stuffed with dense-pack cellulose, was essential in achieving the high level of performance and optimized comfort that the Passive House Standard delivers. 

Carefully taped OSB formed the interior air barrier, while a vapor-open housewrap was used on the exterior. Most of the glazing was put on the south-facing side to maximize solar gains, but about 20% was installed on the north-facing side to take advantage of the views in that direction, necessitating additional insulation in the roof and walls. 

While the main heat source will be the solar gain and occupants’ activities, any needed additional heating and cooling is being supplied through a ducted mini-split system. An energy-recovery ventilator (ERV) is supplying the fresh air. The large, triple-paned windows in the dining room, library, and stairwell invite generous amounts of light to bathe the common areas that are central gathering places for family life. Marble countertops take center stage in the kitchen while the trendy brass hardware adds warmth.
results.name: Tour NJ's 1st Certified Passive House!

group.name: NY Passive House (NYPH) Meet up: Northern NEW JERSEY

results.description:
JC Flexlife is hosting a donation-based bootcamp at Sacred Souls Yoga Studio!


 JC Flexlife offers a fitness program to create habits that will enable you to perform at an optimal level. The goal is to immerse you in activities that will help you realize your true physical and mental strength. Every workout will start with a warm up and end with a cool down. Exercises consist of push ups, planks, squats, crunches, and every variation in between. Normally, we incorporate the park's natural offerings (hills, stairs, curbs, benches, etc.) into the workout. However, during the winter months, we will focus on indoor exercises that do not require any special equipment. Modifications to exercises will also be provided to accommodate various fitness levels. At the end of the day, we're here to enjoy the earth, push limits, and have fun.

$10 suggested donation
results.name: Bootcamp with JC Flexlife

results.description:
As seen in the CNBC Documentary The Bitcoin Uprising.

Starting at 6:00 p.m. Bitcoin Center NYC welcomes Satoshi Square for a night of spontaneous Bitcoin trading in a LIVE open outcry trading pit. Buy or sell Bitcoins with Satoshi Square and others, or just observe and enjoy a party among fellow Bitcoin enthusiasts. Open bar!

This event is perfect for expert and novice traders as well as exhibitors, vendors, hardware and software developers, educators, students, media, and anyone wanting to be acquainted with the technology. Talk to our experts and get feedback concerning Bitcoin-related startups.

No matter the focus of your Bitcoin interest or your expertise level, you are welcome. Bring a friend who might have read or heard something about Bitcoin. With our assistance he or she will leave with a better understanding and their first electronic or paper wallet. 

All trading is organic, spontaneous, and occurs directly between sellers and buyers. There are no intermediaries, and no fees as we are neither a trading floor nor a brokerage. Drinks and hospitality are courtesy of Bitcoin Center NYC. 

Details follow. See you there!

Every Thursday Night

6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m.

Bitcoin Center NYC

25 Cleveland Place

New York, NY 10012

Find Bitcoin Center NYC on Facebook, LinkedIn, Meetup, and Twitter.

All guests of Bitcoin Center NYC are required to sign in.  Media must RSVP using [masked].

results.description:
Who: Joel and Moshe will be the hosts of the meetup. Please find them if you need belay partners.


Where: Brooklyn Boulders 575 Degraw St, Brooklyn, NY 11217

When: We usually climb between 6pm and 9pm. There is no strict start time and the organizers try their best to be there around 5pm. If you are new, please feel free to warm up on an easy bouldering wall and find us later if you need a belay partner.

Transportation: By subway: Take the 2, 3, 4, 5, N, Q, R, B, or D to Atlantic-Pacific, transfer to the R for one stop to Union St. Walk 2 blocks north, turn left on Degraw, we are the last door on the right side of the street.

Cost/Discount: get a meetup discount if you sign up with our group which gives you $19 entrance + FREE gear rentals. You can bring your friends and they will get the same discount from us. Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount and free rentals.

How to meet us: If you need a belay partner, come find the organizer(s). Come say hi even if you don't need a partner. Sometimes we grab drinks/food apres-climb.

Notice to beginners: if you have never ever climbed or belayed before you will need to take a class - it takes place every night at 7pm. There is a nominal fee for this. What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. I usually get to the gym around 6pm, and either boulder at the entrance wall or top-rope in the main room. I post a comment what I'm wearing that day the afternoon of.

Here is the link to BKB: </a><a target="_blank"><a target="_blank"></a><a target="_blank">http://www.brooklynboulders.com</a>;;

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.
results.how_to_find_us: hi, just ask at the front desk for location of rock & ice meetup group when checking in :)
results.name: Midweek Climbing at Brooklyn Boulders (Group Discount)

HTML is used to describe the content of a site, and CSS is used to style websites including colors and fonts.

Together, they can be used to build functional and beautiful websites. Come be introduced to the wonderful world of HTML and CSS and get your hands on some introductory code! You'll leave with a basic web page created and a new understanding of the fundamentals of programming.

Come out and learn how to build websites from people that are paid to teach it.

results.description:
A visit to the Museum of Chinese in America with FREE ADMISSION DAY meeting 6pm in front of the museum. 

Dinner in Chinatown after the museum visit.  Possibly good 'ol Cantonese food or Malaysian or Vietnamese?  We'll decide the night of.  Lobster fried rice anyone?  See photo below.

Founded in 1980, the Museum of Chinese in America (MOCA) is dedicated to preserving and presenting the history, heritage, culture and diverse experiences of people of Chinese descent in the United States.  The greatly expanded MOCA at 215 Centre Street is a national home for the precious narratives of diverse Chinese American communities, and strives to be a model among interactive museums.

The Museum promotes dialogue and understanding among people of all cultural backgrounds, bringing 160 years of Chinese American history to vivid life through its innovative exhibitions, educational and cultural programs. MOCA welcomes diverse visitors and participants to its broad array of exhibits and programs.  MOCA’s expansion accommodates its range of visitors which include: New Yorkers, domestic and international visitors, neighborhood residents, students and school groups from local and regional schools.

Current Exhibitions...  http://www.mocanyc.org/exhibitions/current/

Collections...   http://www.mocanyc.org/collections/


Possible dinner suggestion - Congee Bowery, 207 Bowery, New York, NY 10002 b/t Spring St & Rivington St with their unique LOBSTER FRIED RICE?

Hope to see everyone at this great opportunity to learn, experience, reflect, and support the Chinese community.


Cheers!

Will

Disclaimer:  http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer
results.name: Museum of Chinese in America visit (Free Admission) & Dinner!

results.description:
Join the NJ LGBT Chamber on Thursday, November 5th, at one of New Jersey's premier cultural institutions, the Montclair Art Museum, for their November First Thursday Night event.  It's an evening of art & culture - and networking.

Museum admission is free.  Tour the MAM galleries from 5 to 9 p.m., to view their permanent collection and their current exhibitions, Illustrations and Literary Themes in American Art: Works from the Collection,  Eric Carle: Animals and Friends and Work and Leisure in American Art: Selected Works from the Collection.  And featured on MAM's outdoor video monitors is Peggy Ahwesh's video Warm Objects (pictured above).  "The video was produced in close collaboration with the engineering research center MIRTHE (Mid-InfraRed Technologies for Health and the Environment), an organization dedicated to the development of optical trace gas sensing systems."

The museum will be offering hourly gallery tours, live music and interactive entertainment.  There will also be a cash bar provided by one of Montclair's premier restaurants.  


From 6pm to 9pm the LGBT Chamber of Commerce's board of directors will be there networking and helping you to make the business and social connections you need.  Just look for our table in the museum's rotunda.

Parking is ample in the museum's parking lot and all adjacent streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the Chamber's Table in the Rotunda
results.name: ART AND NETWORKING

results.description:
Would you like to -

• Become a more confident public speaker?

•Feel more at-ease during business meetings and social occasions?

•Make new friends, in a supportive and encouraging environment?

The friendly people at Pride Toastmasters would love to help you improve your public speaking skills, as you boost your leadership and self confidence skills! We focus on making our guests very welcome. We meet every Thursday from 6:15 p.m. until 7:25 at the LGBT Center, 208 W 13th St, New York, NY 10011. If you arrive early, expect to be warmly greeted and given an overview of what to expect during the fun, informative and engaging meeting! 

By the way, there’s nothing for you to prepare in advance of our meeting, no fee to pay as our guest and no pressure to join.  Please do visit and sample this exciting option for personal and professional growth!

An average of 20 members and guests attend each Pride Toastmasters meeting. Since most aren't members of Meetup, the attendance figures shown here are always much lower.

Please visit our web site at http://www.PrideToastmasters.com
results.how_to_find_us: For Room Assignment Please Check the Room Assignment List in the Lobby
results.name: Visit Pride Toastmasters-Public Speaking & Leadership Meetup

group.name: Pride Toastmasters - Public Speaking and Leadership Meetup

results.description:
Graybar Toastmasters is open to all who wish to improve their public speaking and leadership skills. In addition, this is a great way to network with a dynamic and diverse group of professionals.

Founded in 1954, we are one of the oldest Toastmasters clubs in New York City. We are a friendly club with members dedicated to helping each other become better speakers.

We meet from 6:15pm to 8:15pm on the 1st and 3rd Thursdays of each month in the same location. 

Our meetings are structured to allow everbody participate, practice and learn.

In our meetings the members of the club take different roles that allow them to practice and improve their public speaking and leadership skills by completing different projects.

The different roles include giving prepared presentations, chairing the meeting, improvising a short speech, telling a joke, giving feedback to speakers, evaluating the whole meeting, among others, all in a very friendly and supportive environment.

People who RSVP this meetup attend as guests. They introduce themselves at the beginning of the meeting and give feedback at the end, and some of them may participate in an improv exercise, this is an opportunity for you to check out the club coming to one or a couple of meetings, and decide if you want to join as an active member. 

To learn more about Toastmasters International please visit http://www.toastmasters.org/

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: 28 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison in New York City. To enter, please press buzzer #2 outside the red door for the Gallery/Lounge on the 1st Floor. PLEASE attend the meeting only if you RSVP since the space available is limited.
results.name: Graybar Toastmaster meeting!

group.name: Graybar Toastmasters - Become a skilled speaker!

results.description: For this meeting, we'll have read everything up to the end of Chapter 1 (i.e. week 1)  and done all the practices in Week 1. We'll be discussing any ah-ha moments from what we read, the practices & going through the suggested study guide on page 50.

results.description:
STSANY welcomes NEW MEMBERS, FIRST-TIMERS, Pros, Non-Pros, Semi-Pros and invited GUESTS to this workshop on Thursday, November 5 and all those in the future-TBA. 

Meetup Fees: Members: $20; Participating Guests; $15; Observers: $10. Policy: Exact amount in cash at the door.

Please arrive 10 minutes prior to the meetup, if possible, as elevators are busy at that hour.

 ***RSVP DEADLINE is 10:00 p.m. on Wednesday, November 4 for this November 5 meetup. You MUST RSVP on the posting page, and DOUBLE-CONFIRM by November 4, even if you already RSVPd. If you miss the deadline and would like to attend, please send me an email and include your email address and phone number. I will respond!

***ATTENTION "Looking for Christmas" HOLIDAY EVENT VOLUNTEERS: Be sure to bring your written songs, poems, stories and what you will say to the audience to all workshops, so I can put the program together, in writing. You must attend this workshop and others during November and December to work on your material. 

IMPORTANT: ATTENTION New Holiday Volunteers: Spots are still open for our December 17 and 27 events. You must contact me IMMEDIATELY if you wish to volunteer, AND attend at least two workshops in November to be considered for one or both of these two events. We will present some solos and group numbers as part of our holiday programs.

***IMPORTANT NEW POLICY: YOU MUST DOUBLE CONFIRM YOUR "YES" RSVP or change it by one day prior to any meetup to avoid no-shows or last minute cancellations, even it you have already RSVPd before the deadline. It takes time and effort to schedule a meetup, SO PLEASE BE CONSIDERATE by adhering to this policy. Thank you!

All workshops benefit members who want to improve their vocal, acting  and instrumental technique and interpretation. They provide a safe, supportive, AFFORDABLE, enjoyable atmosphere which addresses self-confidence, stage fright and other matters important to our members. Workshops are a first step in providing performance and volunteer opportunities.

MEETUPS serve several purposes: 

* Learning: You are given instruction in singing and acting technique and interpretation, and you also learn from watching and listening to others. 

* Networking: You are encouraged to exchange information with other members (before, at a break and after the meetup) with whom you feel an affinity, personally and/or performance-wise, and to possibly collaborate with them on  STSANY projects or outside the meetup;

* Volunteering: Please volunteer to be an assistant organizer (talk to me about your special talents!), and to help out at our various events;

* Social: Enjoy meeting and getting to know others either before, during a break, or after meetup is over.

IMPORTANT! Although I ALWAYS send updates, if necessary, be sure to keep checking the postings for meetups and your emails about the day and time of each meetup. Weather conditions, illness and unforeseen events can cause cancellations. 

What to bring to all meetup workshops: (Please read, carefully!) 

 Singers: Bring 2 contrasting songs of any style (entire sheet music) - 2 copies, please. If you don't have written songs, let me know and I can provide some at the meetup.

NOTE! If you don't wish to sing solo, please join us in our group numbers. Getting started is the important thing.  The shyness will subside, little by little.

Actors: Bring 2 contrasting monologues, poems or recitations - 2 copies, please.

Instrumentalists: Be prepared to play one or two contrasting pieces of any style.

YOU ARE ENCOURAGED TO RECORD the meetups for continued learning and inspiration!

NOTE: PRIVATE LESSONS are offered from 11:00 a.m to 8:00 p.m., by appointment, on weekdays/nights, and on Saturdays (sometimes Sundays) from 10:00 a.m.-1:00 p.m. Member discount cost: $65 for 45 minutes. Some further discounts may be available. Read your emails. RSVP on each posting, separately, for lessons and kindly adhere to all the details.

NOTE: TO read about STSANY's GOALS and reviews, click on pages: http://www.meetup.com/SOMETHING-TO-SING-ABOUT-IN-NEW-YORK/about/

To see and hear members perform, please VISIT and SUBSCRIBE TO our youtube channel by clicking on this link: https://www.youtube.com/user/AlmaMusica/videos?view_as=public

Be inspired and live your DREAMS! Carpe diem!

All the best,

Anna Bartos

www.annabartos.com

Founder-Director, STSANY since 2010

Founder-Director, Flor y Canto Chamber Ensemble since 1998

NYU Vocal Faculty from[masked] 

REVIEWS by STSANY members, fellow performers and audience members: 

Anna Bartos is not only a superb singing teacher (she knows her music), she is an equally excellent coach, which is a rarity among singing teachers. She is also capable of imparting manyhelpful nuggets of information about the process of singing and performing that one doesn't usually receive from one's teacher. I found her instruction of enormous value.___. P. Vincent, NYC actor, playwright and STSANY showcase performer.

It was a wonderful session w/a warm, knowledgeable & insightful instructor & in great company!____Allyson, Member, STSANY

Great session; good, helpful feedback; supportive.____Barbara, Member, STSANY

“ Fortunately for me I had the pleasure of Anna helping me with my singing technique which is something that I have always to do. I am looking forward to more meetups and meeting new people. You should all attend this meetup whether you are experienced or a beginner (like me). You will be able to discover something so unique and wonderful about yourself with this group. I can guarantee it! ”______Chels, Members, STSANY

An excellent meetup! Anna knows her stuff and helped me improve my performances; the other members/performers are talented and friendly and fun."____Glen, Member, STSANY

The MUSICALE was a wonderfully diverse program in an intimate setting. I found the preliminary workshops extremely helpful in putting a role I'd worked on (for longer than I'd like to say) into a historical, musical, and linguistic framework. I am eager to do more! Anna Bartos is knowledgeable about a broad range of musical styles and genres, acting and character development as well as singing. I would definitely like to perform in this type of event again. For me, once a season would be good (3-4 times a year)."____Rebecca, Member of STSANY (Musicale on 1/19/14)

Amazing event. Thank you, Anna for holding the musicale. I am also glad to meet new singers.___Saadat, Member of STSANY

What a delightful surprise! One often doesn't know what to expect of a showcase! Congratulations to Anna, a real pro, and an impressive mentor to a diverse array of talent. The 'meet-up' seems to be a real resource for both the performers and those of us in the audience.  Keep up the good work!____Mary Jay, Seasoned Senior Performer

It was a privilege to work with Anna Bartos on this 9/11 memorial concert. All of the performers were of high caliber and the audience rewarded our efforts with heartfelt applause. The program, with its mixture of styles and its emphasis on Americana, was just perfect for the anniversary date. I had a great time yesterday. It was a meaningful and well-organized concert.___ Moshe Knoll, Classical pianist.

Thank you so much for inviting us to perform on this wonderful 9/11 concert.___Rosa Hyewon, Classical Guitarist
results.how_to_find_us: Sign in at the Security Desk to gain access to the building. BE SURE TO HAVE MY NAME AND SUITE NUMBER WITH YOU!

results.description:
This is an opportunity to practice Japanese conversation, and discuss and study the grammar, particles, Kanji, and culture. The topic varies among all these, according to what people are interested in talking about and the natural flow of conversation.

Members of all levels are welcome, from absolute beginners on up, and there is never a prerequisite. Native speakers are also encouraged to attend, both to lend their expertise and to receive the benefit of a look at the structure of Japanese from an outside linguistic perspective.

Here's a photo of the area where we meet, for reference:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The meeting is free, with no membership dues, hourly costs, or other expenses.

 

==> Learning & Practice RESOURCES

Various materials http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/thread/3199165/0#[masked]

KANJI http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1175397
KATAKANA http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1198386
HIRAGANA http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/forum/1198387

Please click over DISCUSSIONS ->Message Board, then select your favorite topic. Have a lot of FUN learning about Nihon & Nihongo! http://www.meetup.com/Japanese-Culture/messages/boards/

Fortune Magazine projects that between 2006 and[masked],000 Millionaires will be Created through Real Estate Investing because of the recession. It is our Mission to bring that prediction to Fruition. Will you be one of those Millionaires?

######For the MEETING ADDRESS you MUST RSVP with your FULL NAME, EMAIL ADDRESS, and BEST PHONE #.

We offer Free Meetings, and Real Estate Investing Training CLASSES that cost, and have helped people transition from Wanting to invest, to BECOMING Real Estate Investors. From an investor that is only making a little extra money and still working for someone else, to a SUCCESSFUL Real Estate Investor who is in charge of how much he or she makes and has the option to never work for anyone else ever again. Gain a team of Investors, Real Estate Agents, Tax & Legal Professionals, Contractors and more, to really get your Business Started!

On THURSDAY we will discuss:

•  Our Recent Deals, and the steps we took to Complete them

•  Tax Write Offs and Creative Ways to Acquire Properties

•  Wholesaling, Fix and Flips, Buy and Holds, and more

We will:

•  Help you figure out how many properties You Personally Need to Acquire to Reach your Financial Goal

•  Discuss how you can be apart of our future Deals

•  Give you the opportunity to Network and share in the stories of New Investors and Seasoned Investors

•  And much, much more

RSVP TO RECEIVE THE MEETING ADDRESS, FOR THIS THURSDAY AT 6:30PM!

“The critical ingredient is Getting off your Butt and Doing Something. It’s as simple as that. A lot of people have Ideas, but there are a Few who decide to Do Something about them Now. Not tomorrow. Not next week. But Today. The true Entrepreneur is a doer, not a dreamer.” – Noel Bushnell, Entrepreneur

“The Way to Get Started is to Quit talking and Begin Doing”  – Walt Disney, co-founder of the Walt Disney Company

results.description:
We have short notice for this month's meetup because our speaker only has one day in New York and he has decided to spend it with us.  

About the talk:


I will demonstrate open source work I have done which makes it easy to access and map US Census Data in R. That work has resulted in several R packages, including the popular package choroplethr.


About Ari:

Ari Lamstein is a software engineer and data analyst in San Francisco, California. He has over 10 years experience working at startups and large companies in San Francisco. He recently created his own consulting company, Lamstein Consulting LLC.

Thank you to Collective for hosting us.

Space is limited so we are going to close RSVPs the day before and we will need your full name for security.  So please include that with your registration.

Pizza starts at 6:30, the talk begins at 7 and then we'll go to a local bar.

results.description:
Learn more about human trafficking here: FightSlaveryNow.Org

 Special Event:
Ozark Henry Benefit Concert to fight human trafficking

Limited seating almost at capacity! Act promptly if interested.Amazing venue if you have not previously visited.

This is a benefit with a 'suggested donation' of $20, or whatever you can afford.

Multi-platinum artist Ozark Henry was just appointed as the United Nations' Belgium Goodwill Ambassador against human trafficking. Using his popularity to bring increased visibility in the fight against this modern form of slavery, he is performing a benefit concert and Q&A at the Morgan Library (NYC) on Nov. 5th, in partnership with the Blue Heart Campaign and the UN Trust Fund for Victims of Human Trafficking.


If you would like to go, please RSVP to Michael Alexander at:  [masked]

www.ozarkhenry.com
www.facebook.com/ozarkhenryofficial
www.twitter.com/ozarkhenry


Schedule
6:30 PM Doors open
7:00 PM Q & A with Ozark Henry, Geert De Proost (Flanders House) and intro UNODC & Blue Heart Campaign (trust fund victims human trafficking). Simone Monasebian, director of UNOCD New York and Bénédicte Frankinet (Belgian Ambassador in New York)
7:30 PM Concert
8:30 PM Reception
9:15 PM End

​ “Every time I visit Brussels by car, I notice them, young kids begging at traffic lights, systematically. Kids who were dropped off and later picked up by a van. Do you ever wonder: Who are these kids? Whose kids are they? Who takes care of them? Shouldn’t they be at school? Who’s making them do this? How come no one is stopping this? And if we do wonder, we don’t get involved, and then go on with our own lives, rocking in the free world. Human trafficking is a hidden crime, but we’ve all witnessed it. And when we don't stand up for the victims, the perpetrator doesn't get penalized." - Ozark Henry

For background, please visit our page on 'Street Children'.
results.name: Special Free Event: Ozark Henry, Anti-Trafficking Benefit, 11/5

results.description:
Landlord Tenant Litigation Workshop with Mr. Michael Mantell, Real Estate Dispute and Landlord Tenant Attorney 

Door Fee: $25 | Early Bird Fee: $15.00 

Register: bzhive.com/nov5NYC

------------------------------- 

New York City landlord/tenant law grows more complex each year. With each new case and judicial opinion, it only becomes more important to get advised by an experienced attorney who knows the New York State court system precisely.

Presenter: Michael Mantell

Michael Mantell is a 1969 graduate of St. John's University School of Law. For over 40 years, his law practice has focused on civil litigation

Michael has helped clients to create effective solutions for their legal problems. He has represented thousands of clients and tried hundreds of cases including over 50 jury trials. He has argued numerous appeals including arguments to the Court of Appeals, the highest state court in New York. Several of his victories have made the cover of the New York Law Journal.

Michael successfully runs his own legal practice and specifically focuses on landlord and tenant law, partnership and business litigation and real estate disputes.

Join us for the WORKSHOP to learn or to ask questions about:

• Residential eviction/summary proceedings for possession

• Breach of lease

• Cancellation or renewal of lease or lease options

• Residential lease disputes

• Sublease disputes and rent control problems

• Eviction notices

• Non-primary residence litigation

• Landlord occupancy, etc.

Michael Mantell may also answer your questions regarding your rights as a Landlord or your rights as a Tenant.

Agenda:

6:30 PM EST– Registration

7:00 PM EST – Workshop begins

8:00 PM EST – Q&A session with the presenter
results.name: Landlord Tenant Litigation Workshop with Mr. Michael Mantell

results.description:
**You must rsvp through www.beginnerprogrammers.nyc (MANDATORY)**

If you did not sign up for the class through the website, you will not be able to attend!


Description


Learn why Version Control is cool, and how to kick ass in Git!

Topics Covered

• Setting up a git repository

• Git basics [git status, add, commit, push, pull]

• Git intermediate [managing your local & remote commits, reset, cherry-pick,]

Requirements

• Please be sure to have Git installed prior to class

• A laptop with a code editor of your choice installed.  We’ll be using Sublime Text.

• A basic understanding of how computers work

• No previous programming experience required
results.name: Using Git & the power of Version Control

results.description:
THIS IS A PAID EVENT. PLEASE PURCHASE YOUR TICKET HERE.

Shaun Johnson, Startup Institute

Shaun Johnson is a technologist, early adopter and helper of people. He is the co-founder of Startup Institute, an edtech company equipping individuals with the skills, access and mindset needed to make an immediate and positive impact on the startup venture they join.

Previously, Shaun was an Associate at TechStars, the premier startup accelerator providing seed stage investment and mentorship. Before that, Shaun was a management consultant in Booz Allen Hamilton’s Strategic Technology & Innovation practice.

He has advised companies across the emerging technology landscape, including smart grid energy, healthcare IT, broadband infrastructure & alternative assets. Prior to Booz Allen, Shaun managed metadata and econometrics as a Program Analyst at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Still a lover of sexy consumer web products, Shaun has also helped numerous startups with product roadmapping, getting off the ground and taking market share.

Shaun holds a B.A. in computer science & sociology from Georgetown University and an M.S. in information systems from The Johns Hopkins University.

Agenda

6:30 Networking and Food
7:00 Fireside Chat
8:00 Networking

Hosted By Peter Crysdale, New York City Chapter Director

Peter is the Founder/CEO of StrategyHack, running marketing strategy hackathons for startups and professional marketers. He has a diverse background with 8+ years experience spanning engineering, social good and technology startups. In his spare time, he enjoys day dreaming and cross country skiing.  
Email: [masked] | Twitter: @PCrysdale

Hosted By Joshua Ness, Director of Marketing & Operations

Josh is a growth strategist in the New York City startup community. He used to produce global events for the likes of Microsoft. Now he helps marketing teams learn to think like startups.
Email: [masked] | Twitter: @jcness

</a> Google is committed to empowering entrepreneurs around the world through programs, partnerships, and our products.

Local Partners

<a href="http://pivotal.io/labs"> Pivotal Labs consists of fellow practitioners and startup veterans who have a history of solving problems with early stage companies.

</a> <a href="http://www.strategyhack.org">StrategyHack teaches marketers to be leaders in problem-solving and strategy development through a live-action, hands-on workshop with real startups.

</a> <a href="http://www.justworks.com/?utm_source=Startup%20Grind&utm_medium=Startup%20Grind%20--%20July%2C%20August%2C%20and%20September%20Events&utm_campaign=Startup%20Grind%20-%20July%2C%20Aug%2C%20Sept%20Event">Justworks frees entrepreneurs to focus on their business and their team. Its simple platform automates HR, payments, benefits, and government paperwork while saving companies up to 30% on healthcare. Headquartered in New York City, Justworks is funded by Bain Capital Ventures, Thrive Capital and Index Ventures. Learn more at Justworks.com.

What is Startup Grind?

Startup Grind is a global startup community designed to educate, inspire, and connect entrepreneurs. We host monthly events in more than 150 cities and 65 countries featuring successful local founders, innovators, educators and investors who share personal stories and lessons learned on the road to building great companies. Our monthly fireside chat interviews, startup mixers and annual conferences provide ample opportunities to connect with amazing startups and the people behind them, tap into a strong support network, form meaningful connections and gain inspiration for the startup journey ahead. For more information visit StartupGrind.com or follow us on twitter @StartupGrind.
