Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: This is the 9:00-10:30am Shoot - See the other meerup listed to RSVP for the later one that starts at 11:00am

===========================================================

A MESSAGE FROM JOHN: 

Thank you Monica for doing a bit of extra work to help reduce the prices for events which is in response to our recent survey.  How we made it work was by shortening the event time to fit 2 events in a 4 hour window.   

===========================================================

The Theme 

A comfy cozy photoshoot. Warm hand-knit sweater, coffee in hand, background of vibrant colored yellow, orange, red leaves in central park.

The following is my vision I have (as you can tell, it's not me in the picture):  

I have a blue, turquoise comfy sweater, I'll wear with boots and jeans.  ALl natural wavy hair, minimal makeup to make it look lifestyle. I'll bring glasses as a prop, we can try shots with and without them on.   The autumn leaves are beautiful!

The Place 


We’ll shoot at Strawberry Fields in Central Park. This tranquil section of Central Park was named after one of Lennon's favorite songs, "Strawberry Fields Forever." Location: West Side between 71st and 74th Streets.

ABOUT ME: 

Hi, my name is Monica, I love having the freedom to be creative.  If you have any ideas you would like to shoot, message me and I'll see what I can do to make it happen!  

I'm an accountant turned professional model. I like to have fun with TMD photoshoots! I'm not afraid to try new looks, poses, etc., feel free to direct me or fix my hair how you would like it. Don't be shy! Tell me the look you are going for! Get the best shots possible and direct me well.  Everyone here has something they want to learn or practice or try something new, many are here to get experience directing the subjects (me).  Yes: I expect many of you will tell me to move left when you mean right and to twist when you mean turn... haha, that is all the fun! If you are communicative and have fun with the shoot, you will be taking with you memories to last a lifetime! :) 

Follow me @

https://instagram.com/topxrahman/

The Shoot: 

4 Photographers will shoot 2 rounds of 10 minute increments, with the option to use waiting photographer(s) as assistant(s). The shoot should last between 1-1/2  hours. depending on how long wardrobe changes (if any) and my breaks are. 

3 photographers have 3 rounds of 10 min. each

2 photographers have 4 rounds of 10 min. each

1 photographer has me for 1-1/2 hours (with a few minute breaks every ten minutes).   

HOW TO PAY:


Payment for this meetup is done through TheModel'sDen Paypal account.  After you RSVP an invoice will be sent within a few hours for payment. 

Invoices will be sent to the email you will provide.    

Balance of $35 in cash is due the day of the event, plus any surcharges you may have agreed to. -  Please bring exact change.

==================== 

CANCELLATIONS: 

Please note! -  Events are not cancelled because of inclement weather.  I will make the decision no less than 2 hours before the event.  You will be notified by all the following means:  posting on this event page; email; a text message and a call if no response is received from you.

ALWAYS Check this event page 2 hours before the event starts to be kept informed of the status.  

==================== 

Why TMD? 

So many groups are crowded with photographers, a massive paparazzi nightmare.  At TMD, it's just the model, you and at the most 3 other photographers that help and assist each other.  There will be times for paparazzi shoots. Those are for promotional purposes.  

Models don't expect or request copies of the images. And photographers are not obligated to share.  Sure, if you happen to have a spectacular image feel free to post it for everyone to see.

You get what you pay for: TMD models are interviewed and if their portfolio is lacking, they are test shot.  

At TMD, the models are more than just models, they are business people, hospitable & creative. They understand that photographers are here to learn, experiment and have fun!

Join REIA NYC & Realty411 Magazine for a full day EXPO of Real Estate, Finance & Technology


This 1 Day Expo will be JAM-PACKED with Quality Content Plus, Network with Realty Investors & Business Owners.

 Sponsored By:

AND OUR REIA SPONSOR:

Celebrate Realty411 NEW ISSUES, plus

The NATIONAL Growth of the hot Magazine!

 Learn from the TOP Investors Around the Nation, Plus, Build NEW Connections and Collaborations with Powerful Industry Leaders.

We have investors joining us from many states!

YOUR NET WORTH IS EQUAL TO YOUR NETWORK

We are hosting this event to help increase your contacts

& to further your potential in this industry, so don't miss out!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Meet Powerful Leaders:


The Entrust Group 

Dr. Teresa R. Martin, Esq. - REIA NYC

East Coast REIA


Reggie BrooksColony America FinanceMerril Chandler - CreditSenseGene Guarino - ALF AcademyKevin Rollings - Alcatraz StorageFuquan Bilal- National Note Group  


Be sure to get your hands on our new release of Realty411 Magazine, Private Money411 and CashFlow Express by picking up a free copy at one of our events!

ARE YOU A VIP REALTY411 MEMBER YET? IT'S FREE CLICK HERE

No matter what, please mark your calendar so you don't miss out on this fantastic real estate and finance expo. Our goal is to provide fantastic resources to help you learn about real estate or grow as an investor. We know your time is valuable, so we have wonderful books, magazines, and other gifts to give away.

Learn Directly from Real Estate Leaders

Here Are Some of Our Frequent Speakers


Direct from Los Angeles, California

Learn From REGGIE BROOKS...

The #1 Abandoned Property Authority in the Nation Reggie Brooks, the #1 abandoned property specialist in North America. Reggie is also an international speaker, author and educator, dedicated to inspiring others to achieve personal success through real estate investment. Having risen above a life of poverty, he has achieved what many people consider to be impossible. He went from making $36,000 per year at the local telephone company, to making over $40,000 per month in his real estate business. 

Starting out with very little money, Reggie began his investment career in 1986. After taking a few real estate investment courses, he began investing in rental properties in Los Angeles. He quickly replaced his telephone company income of $3,000 per month with over $4,200 per month from a few well-placed investments, becoming financially independent within his first year of investing.

Today, Reggie delivers his personal philosophies for success at major business venues and expositions throughout the United States. Reggie has also exploded as thee expert on "Abandoned Property Specialist" in the world.

Reggie attributes his success to faith and family, and to the invaluable mentors he has met along the way.

Of all his many accomplishments, Reggie is most proud of his family--his wife Ersoleen, and children Keith and Arlett.

Learn About Owning Your Own Self Storage Facility

with Investor & Educator Kevin Rollings.

Are you looking to purchase a self storage facility but don’t want to run it or really know how to get started in the Self Storage Business?

You have come to the right place!! Kevin Rollings has over 25 years rental experience at various levels of management and ownership. He earned his CSSM (Certified Self Storage Manager) with Self Storage Association of which he is a member.

Kevin is now dedicating his time to helping other Self Storage Owners and Management get the best potential ROI as possible by training and teaching his expert Management tools and tricks of the trade! Browse through the site or give us a call and start now getting the training that you need for Success!

A Special Message by Teresa R. Martin, Esq.

Speaker | Coach | Entrepreneur | Real Estate Investor | Attorney

 Speaking Topic:

 Investing: Making Your Dollars WORK FOR YOU

 The Power of Investment Clubs

Investment clubs can be the icing on the cake in terms of diversifying your portfolio and sampling an array of investments that have been researched by yourself and others you trust. After you’ve attended this powerful and informative session, you’ll be ready to “join the club” to cultivate more dollars for your family.

 Takeaways

 What is an Investment Club?

 How to start an Investment Club.

 What is the best structure for an Investment Club?

 What are the internal & external protections for an Investment Club?

Dr. Teresa R. Martin, Esq. is a sought-after attorney, real estate broker, real estate and financial health coach and certified personal and business credit consultant. As principal of her own practice, she has honed her skills in the areas of residential & commercial real estate transactions, foreclosure defense litigation and credit restoration services.


In addition to being an attorney, Teresa wears the hat of a seasoned real estate investor with a focus on creative acquisition strategies. Strategies that she developed, implemented and taught to others through her role as Counsel/Founder of Real Estate Investors Association NYC (“REIA NYC”) and as Director and past President of the New York Chapter of Better Investing, the nation’s largest non-profit organization dedicated to investment education.

She continues to use her God-given gifts to encourage, equip and help others understand sound financial biblical principles through Generational Wealth Zone, a conduit for the everyday person to achieve financial freedom through tutelage in the areas of financial literacy, business ownership, real estate and stock market investing.

Teresa has appeared as a legal and real estate expert on Voice of America, Real Estate Straight Talk and numerous radio programs. She has been featured in such publications as Money Magazine and Diva Zone Magazine and more.

Get Your Own 800+ Credit Score with Merrill Chandler, Founder of Credit Sense!

Learn how to optimize your credit and raise your credit score 45 points in 45 days while getting on the path to a Tier 1 or even 800+ credit score.


Learn how to raise your credit score 45 points in 45 days! Do you know what opportunities come with an 800+ credit score? THE CREDIT SENSE DIFFERENCE. CreditSense tackles the 800 pound gorilla of the credit system by helping consumers and business professionals to achieve Tier 1 or even 800+ credit scores. CreditSense offers powerful, proven strategies to not only recover lost points due to bad credit, but to optimize our clients' credit profiles so that every piece of data measured by FICO scoring software produces the maximum number of credit score points for them. In this presentation Merrill will show you how to optimize your credit and get you on the path to a Tier 1 or even 800+ credit score. About Credit Sense:

Every credit repair company in the country does the same thing. They send a letter to the credit bureaus that says the problem account is not yours, or not actually late. They have no proof or research behind what they say, kind of like pointing your finger in the dark. They give you a SINGLE POINT of credit inspection.

And what if you don't have bad credit but you still want a higher score?

At CreditSense we do things different. We know that there is a perfect credit profile that always delivers an 800+ credit score. (round hole) Your credit profile is probably NOT perfect (square peg). We bring your credit profile into alignment with that perfect profile. The result: YOU get a Tier 1 or even an 800+ credit score—guaranteed!

How do we do it? Instead of a one-point inspection, we do a 40-point inspection of every facet of your credit profile looking for factual errors, inconsistencies, and drags on your score—and we fix and optimize them! CreditSense does REAL research and checks what is dragging your score down, then has your creditors and the bureaus correct them.

results.description:
Hello Hikers! 

Let's hike the Ramapo Torne/Raccoon Brook Hills Trail Loop.   It is the southern end of Harriman State Park climbs to two panoramic viewpoints and follows the cascading Stony Brook.   We will need more rain for a "cascading" Stony Brook.  It's a 9.5 mile hike and is considered moderate.    Click the link for more details.


http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/ramapo-torneraccoon-brook-hills-trail-loop-reeves-meadow

http://s225.photobucket.com/user/ortnergr/media/Ramapo-Torne-Loop.jpg.html


http://www.nynjtc.org/content/bear-tips-hikers


UPDATE 1 
So I did this hike last weekend.   It was a great hike.  Keep in mind that the hike says 6.5 miles, but this is from the trail.   It's about 1.5 miles from the train station to the start of the trail.   About of mile of that is on the road with traffic.    Parts of the trail are very rocky - more so than many of our hikes.   For a couple hours there are steep climbs and descents with some rock climbing involved.  

If you are driving you can park at the Sloatsburg train station and meet the group.   We arrive at approximately 10:15 AM.   Or you can park at the Reeves Meadow Visitor Center and meet us on the trail.   After parking find the red blazed trail and wait for the group at the beginning of the blue blazed trail (Seven Hills Trail).  I suspect we would arrive to this point 10:45 - 11:00 AM

Do me a favor guys.   I am finding many sign up for hikes and don't show up.   Please don't sign up unless you are fully committed to attending the hike.   If you have dinner plans that night do not attend since we most likely will not be back in time.   If you get invited to a dinner, a Madonna concert, or a personal meeting with Obama you will decline because you have committed to attending this hike.   Thanks!

As always it is a pleasure planning hikes for such a great group of guys!

Phil
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the NJ Transit Terminal in Penn Station.   Across from Duane Reade.

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
Our complete Fall 2015 Hike Schedule is now available on the NJR ADK website at hudsonhikers.org. If there's a hike you'd like to join that's not posted here on Meetup, you may register directly with the hike leader using the contact information provided in the hike schedule.

*   *   *   *   *   *

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:  Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B-7-A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.
results.name: Fall 2015 Hike Schedule

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Thank you to ALL who came to our first CS Pedagogy Meetup this past weekend! We had a great showing and will share with everyone the videos as they are ready. 

If you attended but have yet to fill out the survey, please do! Send me the confirmation page for $50 DonorsChoose.org credit! This is the meetup summary. 

Sean's talk is up on our Youtube page. The resources he mentions are here. You can also check out past talks on our channel.

For November, we have another amazing lineup for you. If you'd like to throw your hat in the ring, please fill out this presenter form

PLEASE ARRIVE ON TIME - We will start promptly @ 9:45am.

> Nathaniel Granor - The Four Steps To Solve Any Problem 
In 1945, mathematician George Pólya published "How To Solve It" a quirky small volume that meditates on the thought process of solving problems, particularly in the domain of Geometry. He presents 4 major steps of problem-solving along with specific strategies and heuristics to attempt to apply. He also reflects on the role of a teacher in helping students build problem solving skills.

This session will present Pólya's work reframed for the context of computer science and proposes the 4 Steps as a conceptual model for both students and teachers to reflect on their own problem solving processes.

Computer Science and computational thinking are very much about problem solving. Experienced computer scientists have an implicit toolkit of approaches they use when facing a new problem. New learners often lack that toolkit. Attendees will walk away from the workshop with an extensive set of Question Stems aligned to each of the 4 Steps that can immediately be put into practice in the classroom.

Nathaniel is Regional Manager at TEALS.

> Lionel Bergeron + Alana Aaron - Engaging All Learners in Computer Science
In 2013 Code.org initiated a worldwide interest in computer programming through the Hour of Code. In an effort to continue to engage students, especially in the elementary grades, they developed Computer Science Fundamentals. The courses blend online, self-guided and self-paced tutorials with “unplugged” activities that require no computers at all. This workshop will look at how these unplugged activities can be used to engage all learners, no matter what the age or academic level. In addition, we will explore how the curriculum’s Play Lab allows students to explore their own interest and ideas through creative programming. The most important takeaways from the presentation will be that participants will be able to identify how unplugged activities can enhance computer science content, how much the play factor can impact student performance and how to approach other lessons to engage all learners.

Alana is a 5th grade teacher in Washington Heights and Lionel is a Technology Coach for D75, NYC's Special Education District.

> Christine Keefe + Glenn Durfee - Using Parson's Problems to Teach AP CS
Parson's Problems ask students to put code statements in the correct order to solve a problem. They are a fun and efficient way to assess student learning of higher level learning objectives. They are "scrambled code puzzles", and consist of a complete sample of well-written code presented in a random order. When properly written, Parson's problems allow instructors to identify what students don't know in syntax and logic.

Attendees will learn the "hows" and "whys" of using Parson's-type problems in teaching and assessing AP Computer Science. Attendees will be able to: 1) Explain how a parsons problem can be used to tease apart errors in syntax, logic, or both, and 2) Demonstrate how to tier a parsons problem to accommodate for different learners.

Christine and Glenn are rockstar TEALS volunteers.

> Gordon Smith - Not so Standard: 5-9th Grade Coding Standards
As the CSTA begins their comprehensive review and revision of their K-12 CS Standards, we thought it was a good time to have a discussion about teaching CS in 5th to 9th grade.
Our vision is for standards that are specific enough to assess the efficacy of CS teaching and curriculum, yet at the same time broad enough to encompass coding, physical computing, and robotics. Well constructed standards will help ensure that we, as CS educators, are working towards common goals and have a framework for ensuring that we are preparing students for high school, college, career, and life-long learning opportunities in CS.

We will discuss the existing CSTA standards and the standards we are developing to guide our curriculum at Codesters. We will also facilitate an open discussion among participants to help broaden and deepen a common set of standards and how to use standards to guide teaching pedagogy and assessment. The participant discussion will focus on how to make appropriate grade-level standards that prepare students for high school level standards (i.e. APCSP) and beyond. We will also discuss the purpose of CS education and how that defines what success means for students. Participants will also learn what standards are currently being used in middle grades and gain insight on selecting standards for their classroom. Attendees will also have the opportunity to share their own expertise about what belongs in a comprehensive set of standards for CS in the middle grades.

Gordon is the founder of Codesters.
results.name: CS Pedagogy Meetup - Nov 2015 Edition

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.
results.name: Bald Rocks/Hogencamp Mountain

results.description:
SO MANY OF US HAVE HIKED OUT TO GERTRUDE'S NOSE BUT WHO HAS EVER BEEN DARING OR ADVENTUROUS ENOUGH TO EXPLORE WHAT LAYS BENEATH IN "GERTRUDE'S NASAL PASSAGEWAYS"?

Please Note: Even though the actual hiking portion of this adventure is not that difficult the crevice exploration will be more challenging requiring athleticism, good balance and the ability to be in control of your body. This hike is recommended for those that enjoy ROCK SCRAMBLING. Once we reach Gertrude's Nose there will be a focus on the exploration of the crevices beneath.  Anyone interested in this hike that does not want to participate in the crevice exploration must be prepared to self lead themselves back from Gertrude's Nose and must also leave a 5-star rating since they have been fore-warned! You can't complain if you fail to read the description.  Whew! - Glad that's out of the way...now on to the description:

Arguably the most picturesque vista in the Shawangunks, Gertrude’s Nose is a geologic snapshot of the destructive natural forces that are slowly ripping apart the Shawangunk conglomerate and leaving behind some of its most intriguing features. The cliff’s name stems from a 1682 deed giving land to Gertrude Bruyn, a settler of Dutch descent.

Our hike will traverse miles of stunning views and fascinating geological formations including Gertrude’s Nose, a great wedge-like mass of conglomerate cliff. Gertrude’s Nose looks like the prow of a great ship, with massive blocks of fallen rock below.  From the peak, you have stunning views of The Catskill Mountains to the north and the Hudson Valley to the east.

But the fun does not stop there!  Rather then walking right over the surface of this natural beauty we will get down and dirty doing whatever it takes to reach the bottom and fully explore the numerous crevices interlaced throughout Gertrude's Nose. (That's right folks - I'm bringing the webbing!)

Finally we will complete our hike through dense hemlock forest and over streams as we marvel at the crags and crevasses of the Shawangunk Ridge.

WHERE TO MEET?

WE WILL START AT THE UPPER PARKING AREA ADJACENT TO LAKE MINNEWASKA ALL THE WAY UP THE HILL AFTER PASSING THROUGH THE MAIN ENTRANCE GATE.

Distance:  approx 8 miles

Hiking Pace:  Up to 2.0 mph - In the Crevices it will be Slow but physically challenging

Estimated Hike Time:  7 hours

Difficulty:  Advanced Beginner/Intermediate - Rocky Terrain and Crevices with possible exposures - I will bring a 50 ft. handline to help navigate any hard terrain.

Current Weather Forecast: Cloudy with a high of 61 Degrees 

Fee: $10. per car

RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Raincoat/Windbreaker

• Hiking Poles (if desired)

• "Scrambling" Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• Headlamp with spare batteries - Home Depot has a great 100 lumen headlamp for only $12.99!

• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set

Afterwards feel free to join us at Bacchus Restaurant, Bar & Billiards for some great food/drinks & maybe even a game of Pool! (Venue subject to change based on group interest)

New Paltz, NY 12561

results.description:
Bored with your current fitness routine or want to start working out? Looking for help and lots of encouragement?

Don't be scared by the words "crossfit" or "bootcamp"! Find out how bootcamp can help you make a positive change, and keep off extra pounds during the upcoming holidays. Class is designed to burn calories, build core strength, tone muscle, and help with overall cardio health and fitness.

No experience is necessary, just an interest in fitness and a willingness to try new things. Any level and physical ability are welcome. The coach will modify the workout around any injuries or concerns. You only work with weights and movements that YOU are comfortable with performing. Proper form and safety are stressed above all else!

This class is 45-60 minutes; $0.00 charge! Arrive at 9:45 am to check in and sign a release form. Work out is 10 am to 11 am. You will be asked to RSVP and confirm a few days prior to ensure your slot. Feel free to invite friends; just register guest(s). Check out the website at http://www.heroesjourney.com/

Class starts with a warm up, mobility work, and then a workout of the day (WOD) which may include resistance training, kettle bells, rowing, airdyne biking, jumping rope, box jumps, wall balls, sled pulls, etc. (Not all at once, obviously!)

Make sure to bring a water bottle and a towel (if you get sweaty)! Hope to see you there.

PS - If you like it, try out a free trial week. There are low drop in rates ($10/class) if you don't want a commitment, which is great for extra training or encouragement on top of whatever you are currently doing.
results.name: Crossfit bootcamp

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. See you on the pitch!

Paul

Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop--everybody listens to their own music. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. results.description:
La Plaza Permaculture Workshop Series
http://laplazacultural.com/#4

Introduction to Urban Permaculture with Andrew Faust
Saturday, Nov. 7th 10am-2pm at La Plaza Cultural Garden

Learn to apply Permaculture Design to retrofit NYC to be a healthier and happier place for people to live in. Learn how to use principles of permaculture in the urban landscape and ways to create deeply ecological businesses and enterprises like improving rooftop farms, restaurant farm to table operations, bicycle compost pick up, rooftop edible native plant landscaping, natural non-toxic interior design, and cleaning indoor air with houseplants.
Also covered in this workshop will be learning to design permaculture landscapes, site analysis/design techniques for rooftop farms, city gardens and business models, working with bees, raising chickens and other micro-livestock in urban settings.
Design your life and your livelihood to be a part of creating a better and healthier world for all.

Free to Garden Members!
(suggested donation $10-$20) Hot Apple Cider

We will also take a quick tour of La Plaza's permaculture features including a great compost system, hugelbeds, member supported CSA beds, a bioswale, chickens, espalier fruit tress, water catch systems, our nature trail and the Shad fruit and nut orchard.

About Andrew:
Andrew Faust is one of North America's premier permaculture teachers and designers with nearly two decades of experience in the field. His passionate and visionary presentation and curriculum has been inspiring and motivating students since his days as an alternative school teacher at Upattinas in Glenmoore, PA.
Andrew lived off the grid in West Virginia for 8 years where he designed and built a Permaculture inspired homestead including a 1600 sq ft strawbale house. He moved to Brooklyn in 2007 and has been applying his knowledge to the urban landscape culminating in a Permaculture Design Certification course many consider life changing. He is developing The Center for Bioregional Living in Ellenville, NY with his partner Adriana Magana as a pilot campus for his students, clients and baby daughter Juniper.

The Center for Bioregional Living
Ellenville/ Brooklyn, NY
www.permaculturenewyork.com
[masked]

results.description:
Relaxed walking, slight inclines, about five to six hours. Winter Garden, City Hall Park, Brooklyn Bridge, Cadman Plaza, Grand Army Plaza and Prospect Park).


Please consider bringing donations of canned food on the walk. The "Canstruction" project  at Winter Garden is an international charity competition where architects, engineers, contractors and students they mentor, compete to design and build giant structures made entirely from full cans of food. At the close of the competition all of the food from the New York City competition will be donated to City Harvest for distribution to food banks.

Meet :10:00AM at Broadway and Vesey Street (northwest corner of Vesey Street).

Directions: Take 1,2 or 3 subway train to Chambers Street and walk five blocks south to Vesey Street or the “A” or “E” subway train to Church Street and walk one block east to Broadway. Bring lunch, water, binoculars or a camera with optical zoom lens.  We will  walk rain or shine. Call Friday evening until 9:00PM, if weather is a question.

Leader: Tom McBreen (516)[masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for Shorewalkers members who have paid the $20 annual membership fee, $3 for non-members. Non-members please pay the hike leader at the beginning of the hike or visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

results.description:
Unusual Tour in one of the most famous hotels in the world Waldorf-Astoria Hotel which includes lunch in a famous Peacock Alley restaurant inside of the hotel. 

The tour will include a professional Waldorf Astoria tour guide who will tell us history of the hotel and its memorial stories, will show photographs, and will take us to the ball rooms, service rooms, and restaurant and so on. Tour also includes the access to the lunch buffet in the Peacock Alley Restaurant after the actual tour where you can sit and enjoy the interior.

The length of the tour: 1 hour and 15 minutes

Price: $70. Money will be collected in front.

Start: 10:15 am, Saturday

The Waldorf Astoria is one of the kind hotels. All American presidents stopped there while visiting New York City for pleasure or for business.

There is a short video of the hotel:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EJKsL2l8U3w

Waldoft-Astoria Hotel is unique Art Deco structure. Standing in the center of the new York City but it`s neighborhood is pretty quiet and not crowded. Here, every room is has unique interior.  Waldorf –Astoria was the first hotel that offered room service and kids menu. These two options changed the hotel industry forever. Surprisingly, there is a hidden train stop underneath the Waldoft-Astoria. President Franklin Roosevelt used it for visits from Washington DC to New York City. Also there is an elevator constructed specially for Roosevelt`s bulletproof car, connecting the train and the garage. This space was used only once since then. Andy Warhol made his own video art exhibition in 1965.

Presidential rooms have unique amenities like multiple adjacent rooms for staff, bulletproof glass windows, and an interior design similar to the White House make this grand accommodation high up on the 35th floor the number one choice of sitting presidents when they visit New York. Every president since Herbert Hoover has stayed here, including President Obama, who sleeps here every time he’s in town. Each president has also left the hotel a gift that is now featured in the suite (JFK left a rocking chair), so check back in a couple years to see what Obama leaves. Recently the hotel was bought by Chinese company. Fearing of espionage, current president, Barack Obama, did not stop in Waldorf Astoria this year, visiting New York City.

There were filmed such movies as Weekend at the Waldorf , Scent of a Woman, Coming to America.

There are several residential units in the hotel, located on the 28th to 42nd floors known as the Waldorf Towers. These are some of New York’s most desired homes, the smallest coming it at 1,600 square feet and many with a private terrace. All include 24-hour maid service, a private entrance and sky high price tags—some of these rent for upwards of $100,000 per month.

Many famous entertainers played here, including Glenn Miller, Duke Ellington and Count Basie, as the city’s elite dined on gourmet food and hit the dance floor for a spin. For 16 years the house band was led by Rumba King Xavier Cugat, a popular Latin music conductor who earned his chops in Cuba. There was even a terrace for summer dining with a city view. The retractable roof is long gone, but the Starlight Room is still available to host special events. Just this year, there was a gala honoring the memory of British singer Amy Winehouse with entertainment by Tony Bennett, Harry Belafonte and Jennifer Hudson.

results.description:
Note this is section 2 for new members of our group.  There is another announcement for all other members for the same event.

One Tour,  Three Treasures!!!   (Note - a good 6 miles of walking). We'll experience the lovely Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Prospect Park and Flatbush Brooklyn!  We'll take advantage of the free Saturday morning admission and with any luck there's still be some fall color.

In collaboration with The Noguchi Museum, Brooklyn Botanic Garden is pleased to present a Garden-wide installation of sculptures by the renowned Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi. Curated by the Museum's senior curator, Dakin Hart, the show features 18 works from the Museum's permanent collection that have been specifically chosen for various settings at BBG. The centerpiece of the installation is a selection of eight works in the Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden that interact subtly with the setting’s rolling hills, rocks, pond, and plantings.

“Each sculpture in the installation is meant to appear to have materialized through some extraordinary natural process, but it has actually been sited to connect with the Garden’s rich traditions of scientific inquiry and aesthetic display.” —Dakin Hart, Senior Curator, The Noguchi Museum

There are restrooms in the gardens.  After a stroll through a fascinating section of Prospect Park, we'll take a lunch break (nice cafe in the park - or bring your own).  Nice menu: http://lakesidebrooklyn.com/bluestone/

After lunch we'll visit  downtown Flatbush and see where Barbara Streisand, Neil Diamond and other famous Brooklynites attended High School. Victorian Flatbush, truly one of New York's hidden gems, which began as a Dutch farming village in 1652 and began to develop as a residential suburb in the late 1800's.  Today this group of neighborhoods makes up one of the largest collection of Victorian-era wood frame architecture in the U.S.  Many of the homes contains distinctive ornamental features and thrive on lovely-tree-lined streets.  You won't believe you are in the middle of Brooklyn!

We will end on walk in the Ditmas Park neighborhood, near the Q train at Cortelyou Road for a reasonably quick ride back to Manhattan or Atlantic Avenue for other train connections.  Usual optional hang out for a drink.
results.how_to_find_us: #2/3 subway to Eastern Parkway-Brooklyn Museum station.  We'll meet outside the main entrance.
results.name: FOR NEW GROUP MEMBERS! Brooklyn Botanical Gardens, Prospect Park & Flatbush

venue.address_1: inside the Park on 110th St. bet. Fifth & Lenox Aves.
venue.name: Central Park, Charles A. Dana Discovery Center

results.description: The autumn foliage should finally be at its peak in Central Park, and we'll do a leisurely walk to view some of the changing colors of the large variety of trees to be found there. Meet 10:30 at the Dana Discovery Center (restrooms). You get there by taking the No. 2 or 3 subway to 110th St. & Lenox Ave., exiting at the south end of the station. Or you can take the No. 4 Madison Avenue bus, which also goes to the same location. After entering the park, walk directly east along the Harlem Meer for a short distance to the Discovery Center. Our walk will take us through the North Woods (a forested area which few visitors to the park ever see). Then up the Great Hill (not as high as the name makes it sound!) and down through the Loch and the Ravine. We'll have lunch in the Conservatory Garden, where the chrysanthemums are now in full bloom (bring lunch and beverage). Around a mile altogether at a very leisurely pace. Call or email to let me know you are coming, and if you have any questions. No need to let me know if you are not coming (though I will certainly miss you!). Bob Susser,[masked]; [masked].
results.name: Leaf-peeping and chrysanthemums in Central Park

group.name: MANHATTAN SOCCER - COED SOCCER IN NYC

results.description:
------------------------------------------------------------
Intro
------------------------------------------------------------

Hey folks! This is a shorter, easier version of the skate I led last year. Last year, we did about 17 miles with lots of hill climb. This year, we're going to do 12.5 miles with an optional bonus 1.5, totalling 14. And we're riding an elevator to eliminate much of the hill climb.

The general plan:

* Meet at the waterfront
* Get a quick tour of Downtown Jersey City
* Ride an elevator
* See breathtaking views from the Heights and Weehawken
* Ride down a big, moderate hill
* Cruise home on the waterfront
* Eat tacos in the open air

Optional segment, for advanced skaters / thrill seekers:

* Ride a different elevator
* Ride down a big, terrifying hill

It's going to be a blast! I can't wait to see you there.

------------------------------------------------------------
What to Expect
------------------------------------------------------------

Sights? Stunning Manhattan skyline views from The Heights, a whirlwind tour of Jersey City (the good, the bad, the ugly), and a nice cruise along the Hoboken waterfront.

How long? 12.5 mile loop with 1.5 optional loop for Hill-of-Death

Pace? Approx 2.5 hours. Meeting point? Paulus Hook Ferry Terminal

Time?
Meeting time: 10:30AM
Skates on at: 10:45AM
Briefing at: 10:55AM
Rolling at: 11AM Lunch at: Approx 1:30PM

Food? Some of the best fresh-mex tacos around. Hills? There's one big hill climb and one big, safe, gradual downhill.

Difficulty? This is a high-intermediate skate. A hair tougher than the average WNS, but way easier than a TNS. You MUST be able to confidently skate steep downhills and uphills, in a group, with traffic, and mount/dismount curbs as necessary. In some neighborhoods, locals may give us the stink eye. You must not break stride as you smile and/or give the stink eye in return.

Road conditions? Moderate. I'll scout the route for rough pavement and make adjustments. We may be able to keep it smooth most of the way.

Rests / water breaks? There are several short rests along the route. Water breaks: I've planned to stop at mile 6 and mile 12 to buy water. We can add another water stop if necessary. There's a bathroom at mile 14.

Bail-out? The route has two bail-out opportunities:

Mile 3: 2nd St Light Rail Station, Hoboken
Mile 10: Hoboken PATH Train

We'll be skating right by these locations, so it's NO problem if we need to let you off and meet you at the restaurant! Can't wait to see you there!

Teaser video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LC3faUkMJXo

Last year's event:

https://www.facebook.com/events/267125096822298/

Rain date: 11/8/2015

------------------------------------------------------------
What to Bring
------------------------------------------------------------
Required:

* Positive attitude
* Skates
* Protective gear
* Wallet
* Water
* Footwear -> if you are taking the ferry/PATH, bring shoes/sandals or else risk being barred entry. I have never had trouble boarding barefoot or in stocking-feet, but I recommend bringing proper footwear just in case.

------------------------------------------------------------
How to Get There
------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------
By Ferry (best route):
--------------------

Take the NY Waterway ferry from World Financial Center to Paulus Hook.
Departs every 15 minutes from 9AM to 9:45PM.

Fare is $2.50 each way, plus the fresh air on the roof deck is really nice.

--------------------
By PATH:
--------------------

Take the Hoboken/Journal Sqaure PATH train to Exchange Place PATH station, then come 2-3 blocks south to the ferry terminal.

Fare is $2.50 each way. You can use a stored-value Metrocard but NOT an unlimited Metrocard.

--------------------
By Car
--------------------
Parking on Sundays is widely available, especially since we are meeting in the business district. Look for spots along Christopher Columbus Ave, Montgomery, Grand, and side streets. There are also several paid lots in the area.


------------------------------------------------------------
Restaurant Info
------------------------------------------------------------

Taqueria Downtown

236 Grove St
Jersey City, NJ 07302

(201)[masked]

https://plus.google.com/105962525654622622938/about

------------------------------------------------------------
Disclaimer
------------------------------------------------------------
You are skating at your own risk. Skating in city streets is an inherently dangerous activity. I do not take any responsibility for your safety. Operate within your limits. I strongly suggest you wear protective gear.

------------------------------------------------------------
Wrap
------------------------------------------------------------

Got questions? I'm an open book. Hit me!

Much love to you all. Hope to see you there!

-David

---
David Y. Kay
[masked]
[masked]
results.name: Jersey City Heights Skate

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Come join "P90x Certified Instructor Edward K" (NASM-CPT) on a 1 hour workout experience that will challenge you physically and mentally. Ideal for all fitness levels, beginner and advance. Variations of the exercises will be offered to match your current fitness level.

We all know that exercising and keeping our selves in shape is a great way to avoid many illnesses. Studies also show that exercising regularly can increase your energy during the day and make you feel real good about yourself.


What To Bring: Good sneakers such as basketball or tennis shoes. Water and a towel. Bringing in a snack is optional.

Where Is The Class Held: This workout meetup will be held at Paragon Athletic Club located at 520 E. St Georges Ave In Linden NJ At 11am.

Cost: $5 to cover class and room rental. Cash & Credit Card Accepted.

What Is P90x: Power 90 Extreme is a popular exercise regimen created by Tony Horton. Developed as a successor to the program called "Power 90". It consists of a training program that uses cross-training and other exercise methods, combined with a nutrition and dietary supplement plan.

Look for Edward after entering the building. He'll have a black p90x shirt on. You may also contact him prior to the event at [masked] or check out the facebook page at facebook.com/EagleFitnessTraining.

results.description: Barry will introduce the Rindler space - the foundation for analyzing acceleration in relativity. Barry and/or Jeff will use this basis to explain the Unruh effect: an observer accelerating in the vacuum sees heat (i.e. radiation) while an observer at rest in the same vacuum sees just plain vacuum. We will then discuss the relation of the Unruh effect to the corresponding duality of Hawking radiation: an observer outside and stationary with respect to a black hole sees heat radiating from that BH, while an observer simply falling through a BH horizon sees nothing unusual. We may explore the possibility that any such relationship could clarify some issues with AMPS black hole rings of fire. Caution: those topics may be entangled ;-)
results.how_to_find_us: near 29th street. The ThoughtWorks conference room is as you enter.
results.name: Rindler space, Unruh effect and Hawking radiation

results.description:
Join the Morris Ski Club on an easy bike ride along the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.  We will meet at the Sheraton in Lincoln Harbor and bike south along the Hudson Waterfront trail. We will bike through Hoboken, Newport section of Jersey City before reaching Liberty State Park.  We will bike around Liberty State Park taking time to see the various sights, memorials and monuments.  We will then bike back to Lincoln Harbor.  We will pick a spot for a late lunch and some drinks.

Important Notes for the bike ride:

1.  This is an easy ride.  The terrain is flat and for the most part we will be on the paved bike pathway although we will have a few spots where we will be on the road for short distances.

2.  The ride is suitable for road, hybrid or mountain bikes although hybrids would probably be a better choice than a road bike. 

3.  Make sure your bike is in working order and have an extra tube.

4.  Bring water and a snack although there will be many places to buy supplies if needed.

5.  Since we will be stopping and walking at times sneakers may be better footware choice than cycling shoes.

6.  Bring a camera has there will be many picture taking opportunities.

7.  Bring a bike lock as we may decide to stop before returning to Lincoln Harbor.

8.  The GPS location for the start of the ride is

Directions to the ride location from Morristown:

·  Route 287 North to Route 80 East

·  Route 80 east to Exit 52 Route 46 East.

·  Route 46 East about 5 miles to Route 3 East.  You want to be in the middle or right hand lane to get on Route 3 East.

·  Route 3 East until last exit in NJ.  Take the exit towards Weehawken and Hoboken.

·  Go about a a quarter mile and then make a right onto Boulevard.

·  After a quarter mile make a left onto Baldwin Ave.

·  Make the first right onto Waterfront Terrace.

·  After 3/10 of a mile make a right onto 19th street.

·  The Sheraton will be on the right.

·  Pull into the parking lot to be ready to start the ride.

For more information please contact Paul  - Email:  [masked].  Advanced sign up by e-mail is not required is appreciated. 

If the weather is questionable the status of hike will be posted on the Yahoo and Meet-up sites.

results.description:
This week we’ll explore VIRTUE, the second of the ten perfections or inherent qualities of the heart.

Generally we define virtue as goodness, ethical integrity, and morality.  In Buddhism this list is expanded with the perfections and includes conducting ourselves wisely, willingness to learn, association with good people, ability and willingness to make corrective actions, willingness to help others, honoring truth, making intentional effort to cultivate and encourage skillful action, being content with what we have, practicing mindfulness and striving for wisdom.

Virtue can also be seen as the quality that synchronizes and balances our hearts and our actions. In our culture we are strongly conditioned to frame virtue in moralistic terms of good and evil; but interestingly, and importantly, Buddhism doesn’t use those distinctions in defining virtue.  Instead, it speaks to the process where our intentions and actions are seen as skillful or unskillful in terms of the positive states they create or the suffering they cause for others or ourselves. 

When we take this more expansive, less judgmental process view and remember that we are responsible for our own actions, we can access and open to our natural courage and curiosity about experiences. We can use any positive or negative outcomes as instructive and refine our course instead of getting stuck in negative states such as guilt or remorse. We find more freedom from suffering when we are living wisely and acting skillfully and in sync with how things really are.


The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.


Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Ten Perfections - Virtue

results.description:
I have decided to focus this week's session on an emotional issue that many people struggle with: fear.  After our group meditation, I will open with a brief discourse on the topic of fear, why it is so overpowering, where it comes from, and how we can be with the energy of fear.  We will then move into some prayer and mantra work that can help us to move through fear more easily.

We have a beautiful new location to start up the Project Prema Satsang!  The American Buddhist Study Center on the Upper West Side has made available its beautiful library space, which is perfect for meditation, prayer, and discussion.

Start your Saturday with a blissful spiritual gathering!  We'll come together for meditation, contemplation of a short spiritual text, prayer and mantra work, and a heart-opening/active listening practice from Thich Nhat Hanh.  We'll end by sharing what a spiritual path means for each of us, and the challenges we face in opening to unconditional love for ourselves and others.

Given the space considerations, our gathering will be limited to 25 people. To help cover the cost of the room, please consider making a small donation.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Paul

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

Paul

Central Park is one of the most beautiful parts of New York City!  It is even more stunning as the fall colors are at starting to show below the city skyline.  This opportunity does not last long and there is no better way to experience it than to be with dozens of fun and friendly members of our group plus members of several other social groups! Your guide will share with you the history of the park from its heyday to decline and then rebirth. He will show you amazing pictures  from before the park was there to vintage shots from the late 18 and 1900's.  You will learn of it's construction, design, special secrets and more as the sun shines on a crisp fall day.

The tour lasts about 90 minutes and following the walk you can join us for food and drinks at a local tavern.

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will come on their own.

What should I wear?  Dress for the weather

What if it rains? We will monitor the weather and send out a final notice by 8am on Saturday morning. Refunds will be sent only if the tour is canceled.

This event is being sponsored by The New York Social Network which is a collaboration of several different Meet Up Groups (www.newyorksocialnetwork.com).  The number of RSVP's below reflect only a portion of those attending.  Please only sign up for this event if you are serious about attending.  We have a 3 flakes and you are out rule!  If you have questions regarding this or other events, please contact the event host Dave Cervini at[masked] or e-mail [masked].

results.description:
Let's head over to the waterfront for a Northern Thai lunch at Pok Pok NY.  The food is fragrant and full of flavor.   No pad thai or green curry here but instead you'll find their famous fish sauce chicken wings, water spinach with chilies, and Khao Soi noodles.  

I've reserved a table for us.  We will order a number of dishes to share family style. Please be aware that while there are non-spicy dishes on the menu, chilies are common in Northern Thai cooking.  The dishes aren't extremely hot and the meal will be served with sticky rice to help absorb some of that heat.  

Menu


Yelp Reviews

*Please update your rsvp should you're plans change.

*Remember to bring cash to help sort the bill.
results.name: Lunch at Pok Pok NY

venue.address_1: Southwest corner of 163rd St. and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan, NY
venue.name: Outside the 163rd St. station on the C train

results.description:
This walk will be jam-packed with alluring destinations. We'll start by touring the meticulously preserved Jumel Mansion (George Washington's headquarters), and nearby Sylvan Terrace, a picturesque block of 19th-century row houses. Next we'll visit the the Hispanic Heritage Society, featuring El Greco, Goya, Velazquez, and other golden-age masterpieces and impressionist gems. Afterwards we'll tour historic Trinity Cemetery, then walk south through Riverbank and Riverside Parks and warm up at majestic Riverside Church and Grant's Tomb. Next we'll visit the the Nicholas Roerich Museum, filled with mystically inspired paintings, especially of the Himalayas. If it's not too cold we'll finish by walking down to 72nd St. along the scenic Hudson Promenade, hopefully with a spectacular sunset. (Don't worry about the apparently large limit of 110 people--there won't be nearly that many, due to cancellations.)


PLEASE READ THE DETAILS BELOW, SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED:

DISTANCE: 5 miles to 72nd St., 3 miles to the Roerich Museum.

PACE: Moderate, NOT SLOW. If you want a leisurely stroll rather than a moderate walk, this hike is not for you!

LUNCH: BRING YOUR OWN. We'll eat at around 2:30 PM. Dress warmly enough to sit outdoors for 20 to 30 minutes (depending on the weather) during lunch.

COST: $5 for the Jumel mansion plus $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee. (If you'd rather skip the mansion you can meet us at the Hispanic Society museum, starting around 1:15 PM, inside the courtyard on Broadway between 155th and 156th St.)

ENDING TIME: Around 5:30 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

TRANSPORTATION: C train to 163rd St. For more details, consult mta.tripplanner.org as well as a subway map (available online), since the trip planner is  occasionally inaccurate. Be sure to also check this for weekend service changes: http://web.mta.info/weekender/lineview.html
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be wearing a red cap
results.name: Riverside marvels: Uptown museums, historical homes and monuments, and much more

results.description:
Lets explore the Big Apple...

Trip timeline based on taking the 6A MegaBus from North Station. We'll arrive in NYC around 11A which will give us time to check into our hotel and meet at the Clock/Information Booth at Grand Central at noon.

Sites we'll explore include the NY Public Library, Bryant Park, Top of the Rock (3P entry) for sunset (4:45P), Times Square, Flat Iron Bldg, Brooklyn Bridge, DUMBO, Grand Central, and B&H Photo.

Departure time on Sunday 11/8 will be 3P.

Group will be limited to 4, no guests, so we can stay together. Due to limited size of group, please sign up if you can attend and update RSVP should your plans change.

Participants are responsible for transportation, hotel, Top of the Rock tickets, etc.

What to bring - only what you can carry as we will not make stops back at the hotel during the day - mid-range lens, wide angle, tripod, polarizing and neutral density filters.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the Clock / Information Booth at Grand Central @ noon
results.name: Big Apple Road Trip...
